reviewText:
Bioshock was a genre shifting masterpiece upon release.

Looking back, there are some cracks in its foundation that stand out a bit more obviously today after so many reiterations and refinements have been made to first person shooters on the whole, but that the experience is still such a rich, deep, and enthralling one is a testament to how incredible it originally was.

Bioshock is first and foremost the story of Rapture, an underwater utopia plunged into chaos by its own design of rejecting traditional ideology. It was a city created to be a safe haven for the most ambitious and intelligent people of the world to tap into their full potential; to experiment and create, free from the burden of morals and law found in the world above. Along with this came the discovery of a gene altering drug known as Adam, which when injected alters the hosts genetic code and bestows superhuman powers to them, from shooting fire from your fingertips to telekinesis and mind control. In a city removed from natural order restrained only by owns own ingenuity, the thirst for power eventually led to the city's demise.

Entering this decrepit city as a castaway from a crashed airplane is among the most impressive and memorable opening sequences to any video game I've ever played. It's a perfectly executed series of events, informing you both of what the city once was and the nightmarish hell it became in a matter of moments, before leading you into an astonishingly well crafted world that devours you whole in its overpowering atmosphere. Everywhere you look there are callbacks, visual cues and audio diaries that retell what life was like in Rapture, and how it got to be the way it is. The sense of place and level of detail carved into the environment informing you not only what Rapture was, but what it represented, is an astounding achievement in world design and environmental narratives. There's never a room that feels out of place, or an oddly written character; it all fits together in this twisted world of objectivism steeped in the writings of Ayn Rand, so successfully realized it's almost frighteningly easy to see how a city like Rapture could potentially come about.

Much of this is presented non-verbally, with art deco banners and store fronts, dated vending machines, and various subtle hints at Rapture's history peppering the environment and bringing it to life. The disturbing sounds and dialogues of the splicers inhabiting the city add a level of characterization to enemies that turns them into more than soulless targets, providing a glimpse into their backstories and bizarre relationships, and at times making me hesitant to actually kill them (at least until they tried to).

The world design is so strong in fact that it largely overshadows the core narrative of your character, one which stays in the background until roughly 2/3 of the way through, and then ends in a rather disappointingly cliched manner. It's not to say it's bad, as when the plot finally comes to the forefront it does it in a way that's startling and unforgettable, but it seems almost secondary in many ways to the numerous auxiliary stories you hear as you make your way through rapture. It's there to keep the experience on a straight path, but it's not what drives it.

With how much depth and originality was given to creating this remarkable world, it's a remarkable feat that just as much work has been put into Bioshock's combat mechanics. Utilizing plasmids, the same substances that turned the citizens of Rapture insane, adds a host of combat options to the standard gunplay, often working in tandem with each other to open the game up for dozens of different tactics that makes combat almost like a puzzle as you mix and match the tools at your disposal to find the most potent combinations (one of my favorites was the one-two punch" of electrocuting a splicer
recommended: and then delivering a hefty hit with the wrench). Being able to carry an entire arsenal with you further broadens your capabilities
hoursPlayed: allowing you an immense amount of freedom in how you approach encounters and with it coming a welcome amount of variety.\n\nThe inventiveness and distinction of each enemy you face layers on yet another element to combat encounters
voteText: from the different ways splicers react to you and each other (from running straight forward
helpfulPercent: arms flailing
votesHelpful: to climbing the walls and dropping down from above)
votesTotal: to the intense encounters with Big Daddies: huge enemies outfitted with an enormously powerful drill and far more speed an maneuverability than there colossal diving suit bodies would have you believe. These fights are brutal and require you to more carefully time your attack and fine tune your strategy
votesFunny: often using the environment and traps you set to your advantage as a head on approach is almost certainly suicidal.\n\nThe few areas that Bioshock trips up on are largely the result of the existence of its more mechanically sophisticated sequel
commentsCount: which streamlined the tedious hacking minigame and added dual wielding to make combat faster and more fluid.. They aren't huge issues in the overall picture
column16: but it does make returning to the original harder than I'd imagined and would likely seem a bit clumsy to those who played the other two games first (which I would certainly advise against).\n\nDespite all the years since its release
column17: very few games have managed to match the scope and creativity of Bioshock's world and mechanics (even its own two sequels). It's an astounding achievement in every area of its design

reviewText:
The long awaited Bioshock has the distinct honor of being the first non-sports title to usher in the long awaited holiday gaming rush. As the spiritual successor to the System Shock series, Bioshock is a highly anticipated title because of its blend of incredible visuals and innovative First Person Shooting. Our tickets to Rapture have finally arrived, and everyone is obviously wondering if Bioshock can live up to its own hype. The answer is a resounding yes, as Bioshock is a genre-bending adventure-roleplaying-FPS hybrid that completely absorbs the player and doesn't let go until the thrilling end.

Bioshock takes place in the underwater city of Rapture, built by the homicidal genius Andrew Ryan. Ryan conceived Rapture as a place for geniuses and the mentally elite to be able to separate themselves for society and flourish without the constrictions placed on them by morality and government. However, something goes deathly wrong in Rapture, leaving most of the inhabitants dead or raving, murderous lunatics. The game begins with the protagonist as the lone survivor of a plane crash in the ocean, with Rapture being your only hope of refuge. You quickly get caught up in unraveling the mystery of Rapture as you fight for survival, getting caught up in the different objectives of other sane" inhabitants that usually need favors before they'll aid you to escape to safety.

The blessing and curse of Rapture is the rampant use of Adam
date: a material that allows individuals to alter their own genetic code and give themselves superhuman abilities. Adam is a hot commodity in Rapture even long after most of its inhabitants are dead. Odd ghoulish girls called Little Sisters harvest Adam from dead bodies while armored monster known as Big Daddies protect the girls from harm. This relationship between Adam
recommended: the Little Sisters and the Big Daddies is at the core of Bioshock. Your character needs Adam to evolve and to remain capable of surviving the various foes that Rapture throws at you. However
hoursPlayed: the choice at the center of the gameplay revolves around the sacrifice of the Little Sisters. Will you kill the changed little girls to get maximum Adam
voteText: or will you attempt to save them and risk not having enough power to stay alive?\n\nThe first and most noticeable thing about Bioshock are the visuals. Bioshock simply looks gorgeous. The underwater effects are among the best ever in a game

column18: that the stage isn't a simple backdrop for you to explore.\n\nThe next most noticeable thing is the high level of audio quality in the game. The sound effects are all spot on
column19: from the bang of the shotgun to the whisper of the Little Sister to their protectors. The assorted splicers all chatter when they believe themselves to be alone

Also commendable are the voice actors in the various audio diaries scattered around Rapture.\n\nThis brings us to perhaps the best quality in Bioshock... the story. Bioshock masterfully weaves an intricate tale by allowing you

reviewText:
A marvel. A wonder.

For me, it has a much more value than Bioshock 2 or Infinite, because it was before, and it said it all, loud and clear.

I don't believe you've not heard a thing about Bioshock, it would be a total bewilderment!
Yet I must state there, that Bioshock was like a grasp of fresh air for a submariner, when it hit the shelves in the 2007.

In the thick of of bleak and obtuse FPS games, flooded all stocks and minds, Bioshock felt like a blessing from above. Ken Levine made his brightest shot into the eternity. Bioshock is a Magnum Opus. A real deal stuff. A resurrection of System Shock principles with the isogenic battle system (mixture of guns, guts, wits and magic), with modern, looking-better-than-Half-Life-2-graphics, and deep, dark, sound and comprehensive story. Again mankind was looking for salvation, but drowned itself by ever-growing sins like greed, powerlust, and false infallibility.

A miraculous experience of witnessing the end of time and humanity. A travel to mad scientist inner space. A nice reason to forget about sleep, in my book.

Mark is 8.5/10: the narrative falls down a little in the very end, and there are some other distracting little things on the way through Rapture, that keeps me from praising Bioshock as the-best-my-eyes-ever-seen!" title. But it is still a brilliant of game design

reviewText:
In BioShock you are a survivor of a plane crash in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean. You are able to make your way to an island where a submarine is waiting to take you to into the great depths below where the mysterious underwater city of Rapture awaits. The city is trashed and genetic freaks called splicers roam around, attacking anything that gets in front of them. In order to survive you will have fight through these Splicers and other oddities keeping your eyes and ears open for clues into what has gone wrong, how you may be able to help or how you can escape.
One aspect that makes the storyline work so well is the way it is told. BioShock uses a real time method of telling the story through random radio reports, overheard conversations and audio recordings.
You can choose from a variety of different weapons, anywhere from pistols and shotguns to chemical throwers and grenade launchers. Each gun has different ammo that you can use. There are also many plasmids that you can use. You can electrify the water to kill everyone in it, set people on fire, freeze them and then smash them with a wrench, among other things.
The graphics in this game are good, out of date, but still good.
The sound of BioShock really puts you into the game. From the creepy things the splicers say to the background music, everything fits perfect.
BioShock builds a great atmosphere by using terrific graphics and sound to set a creepy mood. BioShock is truly a stunning game and worth to buy.

Sounds 9/10
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 8/10
Atmosphere 9/10

reviewText:
I can't believe it took me until now to play this game, it's just brilliant. Has its lows like most though but I have to say it impressed me how the story develops and gives you much more than what you could get by just running through shooting things (like you do in some shooters).

It's a different shooter in most ways, let's say shooting weapons is not what you'll be doing the most in the entire game, you'll have these kind of superpower things named plasmids which are the aquired and upgraded as you advance and consume a meter bar named eve each time you use them. Also hacking stuff (security cameras, turrets) is a good part of it if you decide to, which is somesort of minigame but very helpful IMO.

It's kind of easy if you ask me. I spent the entire game trying to save on everything, I mean, always have the maximum medipacks, the maximum ammo for every gun, etc. Every single bullet was important. I regret that choice as I ended up with most of my arsenal and currency unused. Yes you can run half of the game thru just using very little ammo/eve and just melee attacking your enemies with a wrench (default attack). Of course you'll have a lot more fun if you use guns/plasmids which I recommend you to. There are some unbalanced plasmids however, but try all of them so you can see for yourself which ones you like the most.

Also, if you want to get the most of the story you should try to listen as many records as you can, helps you understand the whole thing (you'll find them randomly across the entire game).

You'll definitely have a good time playing this. Worth $20? Definitely, but you can find it for $5 on most sales.

reviewText:
Bioshock: A Tale of Poor City Planning
Bioshock is great.  It is the story of a man who wakes up in the ocean and stumbles into an underwater city full of grumpy people.  In this city it is not only common, but encouraged, to buy chemical supplements and inject them willy nilly into your body.  This seems to have had a negative effect on the general population, but it doesn't stop you from doing it.  Bioshock features monsters and madness, suspense and surprises, twists and turtles, parents and powerups.

Pros:
Atmosphere.  Bioshock's environment is completely unique.  It's a city with a real story to it, and you learn about it from the plot and the environment itself.  It's beautiful and creepy and immersive.  The music is awesome, the art is awesome, the NPC dialogue is awesome.  Bioshock's atmosphere is awesome.
Plot.  Bioshock's story is complex, deep, and of course interesting.  It's constantly engaging, you always want to keep going to find out what the hell is going on, and of course what the hell happened.  It poses questions about individuality, capitalism, government, morality, selfishness... maaaaaan, it's great.
Nifty combat.  You get to use superpowers, but you are never overpowered.  Combat is always challenging.  Enemies are varied and interesting.  Big daddies are so fresh.  They are terrifying.
Length.  Bioshock is actually a long game (31 hours for me), but it doesn't overstay its welcome.  It's most definitely not padded, it's always moving forward.  You get your money's worth.
Cons:
You collect way more money and goods than you can ever use.   You just fill up on everything and have nothing interesting to buy.
Honestly, the guns feel a little... man, I don't even know how to describe it.  Floaty?  Disconnected?  Not smooth?
Conclusion:
Bioshock is fantastic and you will be thinking about it long after you've completed it.  Buy it, yo.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Bioshock
Original Release: 2007
Genre Tags: FPS; Atmospheric; Action; Story Rich
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 8-16 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWBioshock is a wonderful example of what can be accomplished in the realm of video games when great design meets great execution. A FPS at its core, and the spiritual successor of the System Shock series, Bioshock is rooted in a strong and established foundation. But it isn’t just any other FPS game that will be mildly fun and then quickly forgotten. It is so much more than that. The fantastic gameworld design, the gripping atmosphere, the mysterious narrative, the idiosyncratic characters, and the uniquely identifying combat system all contribute to propelling this game into the elite caste. It is a legendary masterwork of gaming culture, and I posit: anyone who has yet to experience it would be wise to change that.

With the high quality of all of the aspects of the game, it is difficult to name one as the “best.” But I would have to argue the most defining and inspired aspect is the wondrous and mystical gameworld atmosphere. The captivating atmosphere will grab hold of you from the opening scene and not let go until the ending credits. The world of Rapture is an absolute pleasure to explore and the ominous, dystopian ambiance is splendidly engaging. And it isn’t just the obvious things, but also the little subtleties and minute details that really elevate the gameworld atmosphere to elite status. The attention to detail is outstanding. Bioshock has an undeniably “A+” presentation.

The narrative elements of the game are also exquisite. There is a main storyline that unfolds as you play and there is also a clouded history of lore that slowly becomes clear as you progress the game and discover the collectibles (which provide backstory). This multidirectional storytelling will keep you curious to learn more at all times, adroitly holding your interest as you make your way through the campaign. Moreover, the well-designed character development leads to interesting and idiosyncratic NPCs that are infinitely more intriguing than the usual forgettable clichés. It all amounts to an overall experience that will keep you engaged and entertained.

As for the actual gameplay and combat, it is quite unique and variable. Nevertheless, I will admit that it isn’t necessarily the most riveting combat system around. But, as you are part gunslinger and part spellcaster, you can wreak havoc on your foes in a wide variety of ways. That, and the ability to purchase upgrades for your gear and abilities will keep the combat fresh and interesting throughout a playthrough.  Aside from that, there are also many collectibles to search for, there is loot hidden all over, and there are hundreds of interesting little things to look at. There is a lot going on.

The last thing I’ll specifically mention regarding Bioshock is that I believe a large reason as to why it is so well received in the gaming community is because of all of the little things that were done right in allowing the player to decide how he/she wants to play the game. For instance, there is a great autosave/checkpoint system that won’t screw you over if you mess up and there is also an option for unlimited respawns (if you choose to use it). On top of that, you are free to manually save whenever you want. Or you can turn off respawns and never manually save if that’s your preference. Also, there is a large amount of lore, backstory, and narrative elements, but there isn’t hours of forced dialogue or unskippable cutscenes. You are mostly free to choose how much you want to learn or how much you want to plow through the game. This fundamentally open design allows for a wide audience to easily enjoy the game.

Bioshock is a great game. If you haven’t checked it out yet, you would be wise to make time. It will definitely appeal to most gamers, especially fans of FPS games, RPGs, and strong narrative elements.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
Would you kindly read this review and buy this game?

If you didn't know, BioShock is claimed to be one of the most revolutionary FPS's games of all time, and that statement has plently of truth to it. It exceeds in almost all areas, but no gem is without its flaws. Unfortunately for BioShock, these flaws can be quite noticeable when you come across to them. DO NOT let that discourage you from playing this game though; it's an experience you don't want to miss.

In terms of presentation, BioShock fails to unimpress. The view of the underwater city of Rapture will amaze you when it emerges on your screen, http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=260940875
and the steampunk art style is very unique, while being consistent throughout the game. Voice acting is perfect without a doubt, and characters such as Ryan Andrew and Sander Cohen will leave a lasting impression long after you finish the game. Sound design is extremly well-done as well: the whale-like moans from the hulking Big Daddies are very creepy, and the game only uses music for atmospheric reasons, http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=260940890
adding an extra layer of immersion that makes the game quite creepy, but never outright scary (which is not what the game is trying to do).

The story is the main highlight of BioShock, and presents themes and ideologies that are very applicable to reality, mainly the view of objectivism. Plot twists and unforgetable characters will make the experience a memorable ones, and each audio-diary will flesh out the world of Rapture, especially in events following up to the game. As for the main protagonist Jack, he's the typical silent playable character that every shooter seems to have, but his background information makes him quite interesting. Despite this, the story is damned near perfect, even if it feels ever-so rushed after the games huge revelation and twist.

BioShock is a prime example of how video games are art, and is one you should not overlook. Even where it missteps in gameplay, it's story and presentation are grand throughout, and provide a unique experience you will not forget and will come back to again and again. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=261227078
There is no denying that BioShock is a game that will stand the test of time.

reviewText:
Bioshock is one of the most expertly made games I have ever played. The game takes place in a ciy called Rapture, a city under the sea created by Andre Ryan to be a utopia, where people's dreams would not be limited by things such as government or morality. You play as Jack, a man in a plane crash that landed in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean, who finds a Lighthouse that leads to Rapture, now ruined and destroyed due to a war created by Atlas, a man who leads a rebellion group against Andrew Ryan, and wants to help you survive as you fight Splicers (genetic mutants created by splicing up on something called ADAM; a substance found at the bottom of the ocean that can be used for a variety of purpose. Medical, entertainment, or even getting powers called Plasmids) and Big Daddies, protecters of the Little Sisters, who hold sea slugs in their stomachs that produce loads of ADAM.

The gameplay is fantastic. Bioshock is a FPS with RPG and Survival Horror elements. You can geta total of 6 different guns throughout the game, each of which are good for certain situations. You can also upgrade these guns to make them stronger and better over the course of the game. You can also collect different types of ammo for each gun, usually there's a normal type, a type good for armored foes, and a type good for fleshy foes. Then of course, there's ADAM. ADAM is obtained after killing a Big Daddy, then by making a decision on whether or not to let their Little Sister to live. If they live, you get some ADAM, but for every 3 you rescue, you get rewards. Or, you can harvest them and get a huge amount of ADAM, but no rewards. ADAM can be spent on Plasmids and Tonics. Plasmids are you're alternative to guns, basically giving you special powers over the course of the game. Tonics give you're character direct upgrades, of which have varying degrees of usefulness. The gameplay has so many layaers of depth and strategy, and is still realy good in high-strung intense action moments. And it's just plain fun to shoot bees at a splicer, then set them on fire, and when they jump into water to get rid of the fire, you can eletrocute them and finish them off.

Even if the gameplay wasn't good, the story alone is worth the buy. I won't spoil it, nor will I reiterate what I already wrote, but know that the story of Bioshock is not only one of the best, most though-provoking stories there is, but the best part about it is that it could only work as a video game, nothing else, as the story brings up the idea of whether or not the player's choices have an impact, and whether or not the player actually had a choice throughout the whole game. It helps that all the characters in the game are very complex and believable. I could write an entire essay about how amazing the story is, but I won't because I don't feel like wasting you're time. Now, would you kindly buy this freaking game already?

reviewText:
BioShock™ is a FPS set in 1950's Rapture city.

You are Jack, the only survivor of a plane that crashed over the Atlantic Ocean. Luckily for you there was a lighthouse near the crash site, but, why is there a lighthouse in the middle of the ocean? You enter it without hesitation and end up inside a city named Rapture. There, you'll meet friends and enemies, you'll make choices and uncover your destiny. But, what exactly are you? What happened to Rapture? Why are you there?

reviewText: Bioshock I don't even know where to begin the good, the bad, the scary, the funny the impressiveness, the uninspiring.  This game has to be one of the best story’s I have ever played.  I went in not liking the game not wanting to play the game.  And even though it did take me about a month or two of casual gaming to achieve the ending because I did not want to play it.  The game play and story won me over.  This has to be one of the scariest, 80's hack and slash style movie, rolled into a first person shooter.  Now if you have read my other reviews you know I'm not a huge fan FPS's (first person shooters).  I do like to play video games so I play them and above all else I love video games with a fantastic story and this has one.  Bioshock is like the Twilight Zone meets Alfred Hitchcock and they had a baby.  Now I think it took me so long to get into the game because it starts off slow and you are leveling your character getting new ability’s, weapons, and getting the crap scared out of you by the slicers and the enviroment.  It takes you awhile to start to understand this game its set in the 1950's in an underwater city called Rapture.  If you are going to play it the biggest element to the game are the audio diaries.  They give you an inside look into the minds of the citizens of Rapture and explain how the city has evolved into its current state of commotion.  There are some essential lines in the game and one of the best is at the very begin as you ascend to the majestic city.   “I am Andrew Ryan, and I'm here to ask you a question. Is a man not entitled to the sweat of his brow? 'No!' says the man in Washington, 'It belongs to the poor.' 'No!' says the man in the Vatican, 'It belongs to God.' 'No!' says the man in Moscow, 'It belongs to everyone.' I rejected those answers; instead, I chose something different. I chose the impossible. I chose... Rapture...”     This honestly does set the tone for the rest of game.  Now if you are going to play this game beware there are three different endings.  Make up your mind at the begin which way to go kill, save, or do both on the little sisters those three options determine your ending.  The game is 14-20 hours long depending on your play level and style.   Now I can't stress the audio diaries enough they are essential for you to get the whole story out of this phenomenal game.  Just when you think you are like this is it this is the ending nope hold on to your hat.  I think that was a decisive turning occurrence for me to start apprenticing this game and seeing why it has a 96 meta critic score.   Now the downside the game crashed on me a few different times. (Windows 7 user)  So just save often.  The story little slow at first but it picks up.  Wallet has a cap.  Hacking certain machines not set up to well I thought. Bots not the brightest.  Now the last couple I'm nitpicking because honestly this game doesn't have a lot of flaws in my opinion other then being a first person shooter :)  Get it love and play it again and again.

reviewText:
As a spiritual successor to the greatest game that has ever been made and very underrated which is System Shock, I have to say I really enjoyed the game so far...Now into the review!

When it comes to the plot here's how it goes. It takes place in year 1960, while travelling in a plane ya had a accident which ya survived in a middle of the sea, yet with a hope ya stumbled a small building with a golden statue at the top with a weird machine inside. After turning it on ya went down to the city build under the sea called Rapture, which fell due to the one man called Andrew Ryan, the owner of this city corrupted by the power created from the strange liquid called ADAM, which was never seen in the surface. Almost all of the people were addicted to it and started killing each other. While giving up hope, one man called Atlas who is against Ryan asks for your help to stop the madness.

When it comes to the graphics I must say it still holds up to this day and looks great, though like with Unreal Engine 3 ya might expect a quality change that always happens when ya loaded a game but then changes back to normal. Basically any PC ya own in and after 2007 will run it.

Now the gameplay...The most important aspect in every game. It is amazing! While the ammo and weapons may be scarce you also have another arsenal at you disposal....PLASMIDS! At the cost of EVE you can use them to either shoot lightning which can open locked areas, create a fire to melt the blocking ice or even use the telekinesis to stop an incoming rocket flying to your face and redirect it back to the enemy! There are also other Plasmids that does not require EVE and affects your status in combat or other situations.

Almost every weapon can use other types of ammunition ranging from armor piercing to the incinerating ones and ya may find Weapon Upgrade stations which you can choose only one upgrade for each weapon so choose wisely! If you are low on something but have some money you can use shopping ventsto buy stuff but if you think you don't have enough money then you can always hack them!

Hacking lets you turn any turret to turn against the enemies, lower the price for shops or change the healing station to hurt anyone except you and you do that by doing a minigame which requires you to place pipes in any order to let the cyan goo reach the end without leaking it or get to the damaged ones. Be aware that the more you progress in the game it gets more harder.

If you think that you do not understand the plot in overall then you might have missed a lot of Audio Logs. From the Audio Logs you can find more about what was the life in the city and/or even dig more about the owner and his situation.

If you liked Fallout's old styled music then you can find em here as well while sharing the newer ones and pretty much fits the game so perfectly. The sounds are also great and the voice acting is quite great.

Overall, if you think about getting the game then....Would you kindly buy and play it? It is worth 20 Euro for it!

reviewText:
It wasn't impossible to build Rapture at the bottom of the sea. It was impossible to build it anywhere else.
— Andrew Ryan

Bioshock pleasantly surprises with an original style and entourage, idea, excellent level design and beautiful interiors. Graphics and quality of the painters work deserve a special praise. Beautiful visual effects of water and mist, ironic retro-standard agitprop-like wall posters — it's a really great job. All of this stuff was flavored by tasty 'Art Deco sauce' and sweet-tempered soundtrack in the best tradition of the 'golden age' of Chicago jazz.

Literally gentle game interface quickly brings up to date. Audio diaries found along the way (which are the main narrative device of the game) complete the plot with important elements and softly introduce players to the basics of the philosophy of Objectivism.

BioShock is a true masterpiece, each component of which is a perfect handmade.

10/10

reviewText:
A truly fantastic FPS.  The Narrative, told though voice-logs and a 1-way radio, does a great job in maintaining a good distance for the player; A perfect balance is struck between isolation (being forced to fight off hordes of splicers alone) and companionship (hearing a friendly voice motivate you forward.)

As for the gameplay, barring a few personal gripes (there shouldn't ever be a hack that is 100% impossible, solely due to bad RNG), there are very few things to dislike.  The wide selection of plasmids and firearms allows for numerous playstyles and adds a bit of replay value.

I'd personally enjoy it if you could limit your armory to just the weapons you use regularly (too many times did I over-scroll to the chemical thrower when just trying to take a simple picture), but this is in no way a deal-breaker.  Whether you heard about it back in the day and are just getting around to the classics, or recently played Bioshock Infinite and wanted to know what happened, this game is without a doubt worth a play, even if it may appear a bit visually dated.

reviewText: In my opinion this is the best Bioshock game in the entire series. It almost felt like a survial horror. The setting story is one of the best I've ever seen in a video game, It's like a game and a movie combined but it's not too cinematic. The enemy designs are what makes this game so good. The Big Daddies are fun mini bosses to fight and also challenging on higher difficulties and the splicers are crazy as hell. The first few mins of this game creeped me out when I was younger. This is by far the most scariest Bioshock game in the series. Gotta love the bunnymasks the splicers are wearing. I would say fighting Sander Cohen was my favorite part of this game. Just killing Splicers while Waltz of the Flowers is playing just feels so... you cant get that in any other video game! It's so memorable! Final verdict is that this game is one of the best fps ever and the campaign is Halo 1 status good. Gotta love using tommy guns and electric buck shotguns.

reviewText:
It is a very good game, with very good graphics and an amazing story. It is a game, which we all gamers dream of: Gameplay and graphics are both amazing.

+For a game that was made 8 years ago, the graphics are amazing.
+The story is very interesting and never gets boring. You always want to keep playing to learn what's going on.
+There are different types of weapons, which you can upgrade at special stations. You can only find them if you search enough.
+There is a variety of upgrades, which we can apply to our body and help us in different situations.
+Your choices in the game effects the end, which is amazingly satistyfing.
+The story, have I mentioned the story?

-In Germany the game is only sold in German low violence version. I don't know, if there was something important that was cut off or only the gore was reduced but I would like to play the normal version.
-There are sometimes desynchronisations in the subtitles.

That is all I have to say. I recommend the game with all my heart. It is a game, which every gamer should have played.
Buy it, Buy it, NOW!

reviewText:
I had played Bioshock about a year after it had released initially, but stopped about half-way through.  A few years ago I restarted the game with the intent of finishing it, but managed to get about 2/3rds in before dropping out again.  I finally replayed this game in the year of our lord 2015, and for once finished it.  Let me get this out of the way up top: The game is 100% worth playing (or even replaying).

Good Stuff:-The setting is super original: an underwater laissez faire utopia filled with the best and brightest, ripped apart by civil war due in part to the discovery of a gene altering substance.
-Combat is pretty good.  Tons of guns (that you can carry all at once!) and a variety of magic powers called Plasmids" that vary from shooting fireballs to hacking turrets.
-Passive buffs via tonics that you purchase/find and equip allow you to personalize your playstyle somewhat.
-Varried enemy design
date: with thoughts taken into enemy placement in the level itself to provide interesting fights.\n-Great level design
recommended: from the layout to the art design.  Levels are open with multiple branches off the main 'hub' of each level that are typically explored throughout the level via progression towards your goal.  Although there is some backtracking
hoursPlayed: enemies are usually placed in a way that makes fights fun and interesting.\n-Water and particle effects are still pretty good.\n-Audio design is great
voteText:
from the sounds of water puddling in hallways to the ambient effects your plasmids make when you equip them.  All the work goes into create a stellar atmosphere that lets you buy into the world.

Bad Stuff:-The first 2/3rds of the game are a bit predictable in terms of how the game delays your progress narratively.
-The last act of the game is a bit more linear than the first 2/3rds
helpfulPercent: and the final fight really stinks.\n-Some people think the audio journals are an overused trope
votesHelpful: but I personally liked them for how they build the backstory.\n-Switching between your gun and plasmid is annoying at first
votesTotal: but you'll get used to it with practice.\n-The hacking minigame got boring for me about 1/3rd through the game
votesFunny:
but some people might like it.
-Most of the textures have this shiny look to them that makes them look like plastic.

Ugly Stuff:-Be prepaired to work a bit to get this game running smoothly. I had a ton of crashes before turning off the steam-overlay and forcing the game to run in DX9 before it ran smoothly.  There are a ton of steam guides to help you fix that stuff up though.
-Audio can hitch and cut-out during combat when too many sounds are playing at once.  I couldn't figure out how to fix this one
commentsCount: but luckily no dialogue is cut out.\n-Physics calculations in the game are played at 30 fps
column16:
making them stand out a bit on modern machines.
-Options menu is a bit dated and you'll have to do some INI editing to adjust things like FOV and proper sensitivity.

Verdict:Bioshock is still worth revisiting
column17: if just for the story and gameplay alone.  It's a decently sized game and took me around 12 hours to beat
column18: with the only downsides being that the final act is a bit lackluster and that the game looks dated and might take some playing around to get it to run without crashing.  But you're rewarded with a good shooter with a fantastic story and world that makes you interested to find out more every step of the way.\n\nTip: You probably want to up the difficulty

reviewText:
With genetic modifications, beauty is no longer a goal or even a virtue, it is a moral obligation.

Are you repulsed by your own reflection in the mirror? Ladies, are you tired of watching all of the other girls get the fella? Gents, are you sick of seeing the girls swoon for the hunk to your side? Nose too bulbous, lips too thin, brow too prominent? Stop in TODAY to Dr Steinman's Aesthetic Ideals to see what the power of ADAM can do for you.* Stop being the wallflower and become the life of the party.
*Individual results may vary. Please verify mental integrity of your surgeon prior to undergoing any surgical procedure. Dr Steinman's Aesthetic Ideals bears no liability for loss of life, limb, appearance, or sanity. Proceed at your own risk.


Some games, as with cooking, follow a recipe. The System Shock series prepared a great dish; BioShock took that formula, substituted a few ingredients, and presented a game worthy of being a System Shock successor. BioShock is not only visually appealing, is jam-packed with sweat drenched palms on the pants audio, but also with a great story that unfolds as you frantically meander throughout Rapture.

Being violently thrown into the game, you are left with no choice other than to go down the rabbit hole, to enter this submerged version of Wonderland; a place that is as dangerous as it is curious. You are informally greeted by a denizen of Rapture, although they do not appear to be a friendly Welcome Wagon. Much like SS2, you are immediately put on the offensive, and will remain that way for the rest of the game.

The inhabitants of Rapture are fighting a guerilla war. They know the terrain, have the weapons, and their leaders will stop at nothing to win. You will pick up weapons and skills along the way that will prepare you for the fight ahead. Being that Rapture is located many leagues under the sea, there will be no fresh supplies, no reinforcements, you'll be lucky to even find a way out of this madhouse. You have to learn to fight fire with fire, in some cases quite literally.


Stand by for a Public Service Announcement...

What are you doing

Cut to Sam using Incinerate! Sam begins to seize and falls unconscious. A few seconds later Sam wakes up

votesTotal: while in the background Sam is walking away and whistling.\n\n"You're right

reviewText:
Difficulty: Just Right
The Bottom Line:  Masterpiece/Superb
Score: 9.5

Note: This Game Been Tried Out And Reviewed In Offline Mode or On Another Steam Account And Or Consoles.

Bioshock is interactive art in every sense of the word. From it's breathtaking art deco scenery to it's disturbing, deep story, Bioshock succeeds where countless others have failed. It transcends gaming, crafting an ethereal existence on another plane. Part shooter, part horror, part social commentary, all masterpiece.

Games like this come around only so many times a year, they need to be experienced by everyone, be it on the Xbox 360 or the PC. A game that is for all intents and purposes, perfect, is a remarkable achievement. Bioshock will take you on an underwater thrill ride that will leave you breathless, shaking and satisfied in a curious, perhaps even morbid way. It forces you to really think about the events and people, even long after you've beat the game. And any game capable of such a feat is a must-buy in my opinion.

reviewText:
This is the first time I have played the first Bioshock and I have to say it amazed me.The world, the story and the gameplay is really something special.

The story itself takes place in Rapture. This is an Atlantis-like steampunk world where a disaster has happened. You go down into Rapture and have to figure things out to help the people down there, but as you play you will come to understand the character you are playing as and the world around you.At first it will comes across as 'do this', 'do that' but you will come to understand the meaning behind all of it. The story for the most part is told through voice recordings (So no 60 minute long cutscenes).You also find old voice messages left by people before they died, that tell you more about the backstory of the world. The further I got into the game, the more interesting it became to me and after I had completed the game I was searching the internet to find out more about Rapture.

The gameplay is fun, the weapons feel nice to use, but occasionally I felt that my character moved too slowly. I played the game on medium difficulty and still found the combat challenging enough. I would recommend that if you play on this difficulty to spam E on every searchable container to get ammo, health, cash etc.This is because medium can become boring as you often don't have enough ammo and keep having to respawn at Vita Chambers.Due to these Vita Chambers, I sometimes got the feeling I was playing a multiplayer game. Because when I died I would just respawn and have to run back to where the enemies were. So death feels like it has little consequence.Many people complain about the amount of hacking you have to do if you don't want to be shredded instantly by the turrets.At first I didn't really have any problems with it and hacked every object that could be hacked, but as I progressed through the game I got really tired of it.As well as guns the game also has Plasmids, which are special powers that you can perform with your characters left hand.These Plasmids, like your guns, can be upgraded.The RPG elements in this game really makes you consider which items should be taken with you and which should be left behind.

The world has this great Atlantis vibe. Everything in the world of Rapture is enclosed, which helps the game to achieve no pop-in and have great looking environments. These still look great after all this time because of the attention to detail, time and effort put in to them. You only see some problems when you get too close to certain textures. Because of the narrowness of the environments and the use of audio, you get this creepy haunted house feeling.A feeling that around every corner something strange could happen.I only wish that the game had given us more open environments and that the watery world outside of Rapture was more interesting to look at.The A.I. makes good use of its environment. For example, when they are low on health they will run to a nearby healing machine, or if they are on fire they will jump into water to extinguish themselves.The enemies are well realised with great acrobatic animations and sophisticated A.I. The only things that feel clunky to me are the enemy death animations and how the physics objects react.Like, when you hit an object with your wrench, it flies away jerkily through the air, as if you are viewing it at 10 FPS.

Note:
I would recommend saving every time before alt/shift + tabbing. The game sometimes crashed, when I did that. ( windows 7 64bit )

Final thoughts:
This was my first time playing through the original Bioshock and it is amazing.There is really alot of creativity and care put into this AAA game that you don't often see.Even if you own Bioshock 2 or Bioshock:Infinite (Infinite has nothing to do with Bioshock 1 and 2) I would still recommend playing it because of the story and how well the game has aged.

reviewText:
Bioshock, Little Sisters and Rapture...
You're thinking of these terms when someone mentions the game. It's probably one of the best games I've ever played.
You have a story line that can be expanded with tape recorders or you follow the normal one.
Much can't be sayed about the story without a spoiler BUT I can say it's suprising and the end is not what you're expecting ;)

PLAY it, BUY IT it's absolutely worth and it's INCREDIBLE, AWESOME and BEAUTIFUL! <3

reviewText:
Would you kindly?

It's Bioshock, what else do I need to say? It's crazy, it's smart, it's intense! The story is amazingly detailed and catching. You play as a man named Jack, who lands in the middle of the ocean, next to a lighthouse after a plane crash. Upon entering it, he gets taken into the underwater-city of Rapture, built by the millionaire Andrew Ryan. After the civil war, the city is not under control of sane people or Ryan himself, but ruled by crazy lunatics and geneticly mutated citizens of Rapture. Luckily you are helped by a man named Atlas, who gives you calls to tell you where to go next and what to do.
In the game, you have an arsenal of weapons and power at your disposal. From wrenches, over shotguns and crossbows, to syringes filled with fluids that give you the abilities to shoot fire or lightning from your fingertips, use telekenesis and take control of other peoples bodies. (Just be careful with those Big Daddys!) These so called 'Plasmids' are what make Bioshock a unique shooter with an amazing story and characters, that catch you from start to finish.

I highly recommend any Bioshock game to everyone who likes non-linear shooters, which are different from the rest.

9/10

This has got to be one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. Gameplay was good, the environment is literally breathtaking, and the story is magnificent.

You play as Jack, whose plane goes down in the middle of the Atlantic ocean near a lighthouse. The lighthouse is actually the gateway to the underwater city of Rapture. Or it ruins, anyway. Rapture, the brain child of industrialist Andrew Ryan, was supposed to be a paradise for the common man, but not all was well in paradise. Civil unrest, class warfare, and add unmonitored sciencetific discoveries to the mix and things got real very fast. Plasmids, tonics that give humans super powers so to speak, is powered by a substance called ADAM". But it destroys the mind with repeated abuse and now it's aftermath roams the streets.

When you arrive
date: you seem to be at the tail end of the Rapture Civil War (a war between classes which quickly turned into a game of "Who Can Splice More") and you are almost immedietly contacted by a man named Atlas
recommended: who promises to help you escape Rapture. Now you must navigate through the city to find a way out. But don't get too comfortable in this city. Not all is as it seems and everyone is trying to get their hands on you.\n\nWhat I loved most about BioShock is that the main story isn't the only story. You learn about the city

reviewText:
My favorite game from the 360/PS3 era.  When this came out it was a breath of fresh air in art direction and pacing.  The plot is amazing, including one of the best reveals in gaming when you meet Mr. Andrew Ryan.  You can explore a glorious underwater city that has gone from paradise to madness through the in game characters you meet and the audio journals you collect.  There are some real standout characters both from physical design and voice acting standpoints.  Who doesn't remember Sander Cohen after they play this game once!
The graphics still hold up today (just finished a playthrough 1/9/2014) with both the characters and backgrounds having great detail and art.  Enemies variation is good in the beginning, but repeat a little to often near the end, just as most shooters do.  Of course, the game has the iconic big daddy fights that are a lot of fun and a real challenge on hard difficulty.
I don't think the actual shooting is anything too special,  You get pretty standard weapon choices (Pistol, machine gun, shotgun, rocket launcher, yawn, zzzzz)  but you do get a lot of cool spell type abilities called Plasmids and get to upgrade each weapon and Plasmid twice.  There are multiple ammo types for each gun as well as hackable enemies, so for what the shooting lacks in weight and badass weaponry it makes up for in sheer variety.  You can literally not play this game the same way twice.
Be warned the graphics always seemed a little more glitchy on PC than it did on my dearly departed XBOX.  I've had occasional frame rate jumps and the electric chemical thrower would cause graphical glitches on my pair of playthroughs on PC.  Check the forums as this game can be a real pain to get working on your modern OS.
The game gets my highest recommendation.  You will see this for $5.00 every once in a while on Steam.  If you didn't buy it for that price you would be a damn fool.

reviewText:
Bioshock has... this unique feeling to it, it doesnt realy feel like a generic shooter with some magic powerups as what the outsider may think when they glance over it. The entire location this game takes place in is impressive and until now rarely done in those times.

But the best part is story, yes the story is the most recommendable part. As the story is told via dialogue most of the time and the rare cutscenes are mostly done for the big reveals or intro's. This game was so good, I bought it when it was on sale and before I knew it I was 4 hours in and was far from bored and actualy had to force myself to stop playing to get some rest.

If you never played Bioshock.. Well you should ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ change that problem.

reviewText:
In early 2010, film critic Roger Ebert published an article regarding his position on video games as an artistic medium. Early in the article, Ebert firmly expresses his view on the matter: “Let me just say that no video gamer now living will survive long enough to experience the medium as an art form.” As much as I respect the late Roger Ebert, I have to disagree with this statement because gamers living today have survived to see at least one game rise above the rest as a work of art. The game in question is Bioshock, a first person shooter that combines exquisite storytelling, impressive presentation, and innovative gameplay into one cohesive unit that stands with any novel, painting, or movie as a piece of fine art.
Bioshock begins with the player’s character, a silent protagonist named Jack, surviving a plane crash in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean. With nowhere else to go, Jack swims to a nearby islet occupied by a large lighthouse. Jack takes refuge inside the structure and discovers a small bathysphere that takes him to the game’s main setting, the massive underwater city of Rapture. According to a recording played in the bathysphere, Rapture was conceived by a business magnate named Andrew Ryan, who built the city with the vision of a utopian community where one could achieve greatness without any interference from outside forces, such as government or religion. However, upon arriving in Rapture, the player soon finds out that things did not go exactly as Ryan planned. The city now lies in ruin and all of its living residents have become murderous lunatics that lash out at anything that moves. Aided via radio by a mysterious man named Atlas, Jack must now explore rapture and escape with his life.
What makes this game stand out from others is that the player has full control of Jack during the entire experience. By immediately relinquishing control, Bioshock immerses the player in a captivating tale of freewill and madness that slowly reveals itself over the course of the game. In addition to scripted events, such as the masterfully executed opening, the player can listen to audio logs left behind by the once sane citizens of Rapture. These optional logs give the player deeper insight into the lives of Rapture’s residents and the events that led to the city’s downfall.
Ryan himself adds philosophical depth to the game’s already rich narrative. He exudes ambition and unrelenting determination to his beliefs with a charisma that makes him one of the most memorable characters in all of gaming. His attitude towards government and religious officials, which he refers to as “parasites,” heavily mirrors the objectivist beliefs Ayn Rand expressed in novels like Atlas Shrugged. The inclusion of these philosophical themes elevates Bioshock above the stereotype that games produce stories with little to no substance. 	Unfortunately, the story’s only flaw, and the main drawback of the game in general, is the ending, which feels abrupt and underwhelming compared to the rest of the game. Luckily, the rest of the story makes up for the lackluster ending with some amazing plot twists that will stick with the player long after their experience with the game has concluded.
If Bioshock’s mesmerizing plot doesn’t draw the player into its world, then its unparalleled presentation will. Every inch of Rapture is painstakingly rendered with borderline obsessive attention to the tiniest details. Water realistically drips from the walls and ceilings. Neon signs flicker and short out. Cheerful announcements fall on deaf ears over the intercom. These fully realized details add to the idea that Rapture was once a thriving metropolis where people lived happy and fulfilling lives, making its current state of disrepair all the more heart wrenching. Furthermore, Bioshock exudes a distinct art direction rarely seen in games. Rapture’s consistent Art Deco style will generate a sense of appreciation for the artistry required to bring these environments to life.
While Bioshock’s story and presentation already place it in a league of its own, the game truly shines in its innovations to traditional FPS gameplay. Throughout the game, the player gather’s a diverse arsenal of weapons, ranging from a pistol to a shotgun to a flamethrower. Aiming and firing each of these weapons feels natural and satisfying. Also, all of the weapons can be upgraded to increase their accuracy and damage among other traits.
However, Bioshock deviates from FPS norms with the addition of plasmids. These genetic modifications provide the player with a wide variety of powers, such as setting enemies on fire, picking up and throwing large objects, and possessing enemies to have them fight on the player’s side. In order to obtain these perks, the player must collect a gene altering substance called ADAM from small girls called Little Sisters that freely roam Rapture’s halls. However, the player must first defeat the Little Sisters’ guardians, huge diving suit wearing creatures simply known as Big Daddies. These intimidating monsters deal massive damage and will take a long time to defeat, but the satisfaction and rewards make it worth the effort. Once the Big Daddy falls, the player has the option to either harvest the Little Sister, which gives the player more ADAM but kills the girl, or rescue it, which yields less ADAM but promises the player a future reward. These decisions not only affect the player’s access to plasmids but also have moral ramifications that play into how the game’s story unfolds. This morality based choice system not only presents the player with an interesting dilemma with tangible consequences, but also perfectly ties into the game’s overall themes of personal growth and freedom.
When all of Bioshock’s elements come together into a singular piece, they form a thoroughly entertaining and thought provoking experience that only a work of art can provide. The story keeps players guessing and presents them with philosophical concepts that other games can only dream of expressing. The presentation engrosses players into a world so authentically realized that it becomes as deep and complex as any of the game’s characters. Finally, the multifaceted gameplay forces the players to make decisions that impact their individual endeavors in unexpected ways. If this is the only time gamers experience the medium as a true art form, I can easily say that Bioshock deserves that distinction. Whether you’re a seasoned gamer or a curious onlooker, you owe it to yourself to pick up this slice of gaming excellence.

reviewText:
A gaming masterpiece, no doubts.
The story is wonderfully crafted, in fact it's so good you shouldn't watch any videos on it just to prevent you from getting spoiled.

Graphics are amazing, on extremely low-end hardware it looks fantastic (minus you can barely read signs unless you get really close, and statues look more deformed than they should be) and runs well, my graphics card is dreadful, at 128mb of VRAM and I was able to beat the game start to finish without having any technical issues or crashes, with a playable framerate. (~24 fps not much on screen and standing still, ~19 fps when there was lots on screen and tons of action, but it felt like 30 oddly and didn't really run into many huge gaping framerate dips)

Gameplay is near perfect, there are two ways you can engage your enemies, Plasmids and normal Weapons. Normal Weapons are your, well, normal weapons, like a machine gun, an oddly satisfying shotgun which I unfortunately rarely used, and a crossbow which I actually never used, probably due to the fact there was no ammo for the damn thing until the last level, where you can buy some in a vending machine, but that's a fat lot of use because that vending machine is right next to the final boss! Slightly less flawed, however, is the plasmids. Plasmids are useful tools that can shock enemies with lightning, light them on fire, freeze them, or summon a load of bees. Now, onto the flaws with the gameplay. First up is hacking, this is very useful, as you can hack security cameras and turrets to aid you against the enemies. Unfortunately, about halfway through the game hacking is near impossible just to hack something as simple as a vending machine, it also kills the pacing as you could be just about to hack as a enemy is shooting at you, then time stops completely as you hack. During my first ever playthrough of the game on the XBox 360, I only hacked once, and that was when you had to hack a Security Bot to progress. Second, is the wrench. It is immensely overpowered. From the second level of the game, you can pick up a tonic called Wrench Jockey which increases the wrench's damage. This tonic is the best in the game, as at the beginning, it takes about four hits to kill a Thuggish Splicer, and about six to kill a Leadhead Splicer. With the tonic, though, you can kill both in 1-2 hits. Wow.

Ignoring the somewhat minor flaws with the gameplay above, this is a must-buy and is one of the best games EVER MADE, and would you believe it's nine years old already? I will note that if you own a Playstation 3, that version of Bioshock is the best, since it has a new difficulty setting called Survivor, along with PS3 exclusive dlc called the Challenge  Room which is not availible for PC or XBox 360. Now, that being said, would you kindly buy this game?

reviewText:
A well made shooter with RPG elements. Good variety of weapons/abilities to choose from. I thoroughly enjoyed the ~12 hours it took me to beat it.

Pros:
-Great combat mechanics. (Telekinesis was always fun)
-Spooky environment/enemies.
-Overall creepy presentation.

Cons:
-You are thrust quite abruptly into the story of the game. There's little to no explanation when the game begins as to why you are a machine-gun wielding sorcerer. You'll figure it out as you go.
-Difficulty is a little weird. Normal baddies are cake. Big-Daddys tended to wreck me. Thankfully you essentially have unlimited lives.

Overall, I'd recommend this game to sadists, serial killers, scuba divers, and sorcerers. I'd also encourage you to 'Rescue' the Little Sisters as opposed to 'Harvesting' them. If you rescue them all, the ending is equal parts satisfaction and horror.

Each weapon has different ammo types that can be loaded in to the weapon such as proximity mines for the grenade launcher or AP rounds for the machine gun. There are U-Invent stations spread throughout the levels and at these stations you can craft various new items such as new plasmids or ammo types. About halfway through the game you get the camera and this will allow you to take pictures of enemies and for taking these pictues you gain bonuses. For example
votesFunny: if you take pictures of the Big Daddies then you can unlock extra damage and loot to use against them. This is an incredibly unique system and really enhances the combat with all sorts of bonuses to keep in mind. This brings me to my main problem with the combat in Bioshock: Its old. Now don't get me wrong I love old games because most the time they're just flat out better games but here the old and dated controls really kills the game in parts. The options menu  is fairly lacking and the graphics options may cause some problems but my main issue is the sensitivity. The sensitivity completely ♥♥♥♥ed me over in combat because it's always too high and there isn't a good scale built into the game. reviewText: A Masterpiece, simple as that, i have played Ken Levine's games and Looking glass studio starting on system shock when i was around 11, some years later Bioshock came out in 2007, and was blown away, the atmosphere and the richness of the city of Rapture sucked me into its hole in the very same way System shock 2 did, while those who have played  SS2 will recognize lots of easter eggs and similarities between the two they are also very different, the whole rpg element is non existant in Bioshock, but of course this takes nothing away from the game as there are various forms of weapons as well as plasmid which are your powers in game adding a fresh new battle system, and possibly one of the most key things at least for me is the story, if you take the time to listen to the audio logs (thank you for not making us read logs ken levine) you will find so much richness in this world that reached its tragic end, one more point to mention is how this game takes ideas from Russian philosopher Ayn Rand who supports her own idea of Objectivism, the novels Fountainhead and even more popular and more closely related to this game Atlas Shrugged will give something to think about, this isn't a game that you just play, its a game you have to understand, how you play this game is up to you for there are choices in this game and a plot twist to keep you thinking.  Highly recommend.\n\nA Man Chooses

reviewText:
BioShock has one of the most disturbing stories ever made in the gaming history. You are basically in a plane, then you suddenly crash and get wrapped up in a war between two factions fighting for power. Make use of Plasmids, powerful DNA modifiers that let you cast incredible skills; pick up the classic guns and kill all your foes. Dislike these methods? Hack, go on stealth, the choice is up to you. One of the best games ever made.

+Different ways to approach the same situation
+Inmersive dark atmosphere
+Moral system that tests players
+Rich in both lore and character background terms
+Strong RPG touch
+Beautiful architecture

-Soundtrack could have been better

98/100 Masterpiece

reviewText:
Here's my 2nd review of the 'best FPS's of all time', as promised.
(Bragging note: dont mind my Playtime of the game on Steam, i played and did 100% on all 3 Bioshock games on the PS3)

Bioshock is the most stylish game of all time.
While HL2 is the traditional FPS, great in every department, but following previously established archetypes, Bioshock revolutionizes most of those formulas. So i'll also try my best to 'stylize' my 'review formula':

Rapture.
Truly, this amazing underwater city defines everything this game does well. From the very start, you feel like Alice, going into the rabbit hole, into Wonderland... Except you're late for this one, it's already in ruins.
The art style is absolutely amazing, the 20's Art Déco combined with the sci fi / mechanical aspects results in a sense of confusion, not knowing if you're in the past or future, which adds to the mysterious tone of the ruined city.

The combat system is also very refreshing, instead of just relying on weapons, they added plasmids, which can be mixed with the guns for fun gameplay, with an added layer of depth. The exploration and scavenging were a nice surprise for me (as an obsessive explorer in gaming), presenting both some RPG elements and the backstory of the city, before it collapsed (metaphorically), through the eyes of its previous inhabitants.
Another unique, iconic element of the game is it's enemies, more specifically the almighty Big Daddy, who provides an amazing dynamic to the combat (i was gonna describe it, but i decided it's best to let the players found out for themselves).

Finally we reach the Story, praised as one of the best in videogames, proving that FPS's dont have to be mindless with virtually no story (you guys know what games im talking about!), by presenting complex philosophical, moral and political ideas, as an amazing social commentary that should probably be studied and debated by the experts of those departments. All of this, with a limited amount of characters, that you can count witth the fingers in your hands. But even though few, each counts as a hundred, with powerful personalities crashing, which results in the infamous plot twists that catapulted this game into stardom.

Now, would you kindly do yourself a favor, and go play this game immediately, if you havent yet (or even if you have!)

reviewText:
Bioshock is simply a brilliant game. For me, few games have changed the the way I think about games ; it belongs with those other great and defining FPS'S such as Half Life, Deus Ex, Thief and both System Shocks. All bring something new and fresh to the genre and make you look at them with awe.
With Bioshock, it is primarily all about the story. Its combat can be repetitive, but with the assortment of plasmids with the conventional weapons at your disposal, the game never gets boring; rather the further you advance, the deeper you become engrossed in the story, especially if you take the time to find and listen to all of the audio logs.
Rapture is one of the best worlds i have experienced, and with the Big Daddy and Little Sister characterisation and relationship, amongst many other things,  Bioshock is truly unforgetable.
A classic.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8RIJaRjTnlw

I started playing Bioshock thinking it would be a straightforward FPS with no depth, but I can tell you that I was pleasantly surprised by it.

Both the setting and the story were really engaging which got me really immersed in the game. Everything from the shooting mechanics to the spectacular voice acting gave the game a really polished feel.

The game isn't as linear as I originally thought, some points you're forced to scavenge for ammo and you actually get rewarded for exploring which is really nice.

You can also really customize how you play by selecting from a huge choice of plasmids which change your character in interesting ways.

One tiny thing that annoyed me is that there's absolutely no penalty for dying, you just respawn at the checkpoint losing absolutely no progress or money. Also, there are very frequent hacking puzzles which broke the pace of the gameplay.

Finally, the ending of the game was highly anticlimactic. It spends ages immersing you just to end it all with an escort mission and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ excuse of a -Beep-, climaxing with a 30 second cinematic.

If you don't mind a minigame every now and then, or a somewhat rushed ending then I'm sure you'll enjoy the great gameplay and many plot twists that this game offers. I really enjoyed my time with Bioshock and it's one of the best single player FPS games I've ever played, so it gets a 7 out of 10 on 60 Second Reviews.

reviewText:
Would you kindly read this review and buy this game?

If you didn't know, BioShock is claimed to be one of the most revolutionary FPS's games of all time, and that statement has plently of truth to it. It exceeds in almost all areas, but no gem is without its flaws. Unfortunately for BioShock, these flaws can be quite noticeable when you come across to them. DO NOT let that discourage you from playing this game though; it's an experience you don't want to miss.

In terms of presentation, BioShock fails to unimpress. The view of the underwater city of Rapture will amaze you when it emerges on your screen, and the steampunk art style is very unique, while being consistent throughout the game. Voice acting is perfect without a doubt, and characters such as Ryan Andrew and Sander Cohen will leave a lasting impression long after you finish the game. Sound design is extremly well-done as well: the whale-like moans from the hulking Big Daddies are very creepy, and the game only uses music for atmospheric reasons, adding an extra layer of immersion that makes the game quite screepy, but never outright scary (which is not what the game is trying to do).

The story is the main highlight of BioShock, and presents themes and ideologies that are very applicable to reality, mainly the view of objectivism. Plot twists and unforgetable characters will make the experience a memorable ones, and each audio-diary will flesh out the world of Rapture, especially in events following up to the game. As for the main protagonist Jack, he's the typical silent playable character that every shooter seems to have, but his background information makes him quite interesting. Despite this, the story is damned near perfect, even if it feels ever-so rushed after the games huge revelation and twist.

I could end the review here, as the story is something that alone should be able to sell this game instantly, no strings attached. However, how does BioShock sell as an FPS? The game features an arsenal of weapons from a flamethrower to a machine gun, and are all quite standard. The sense of conserving ammo that the game has at first is very intense, however later on you will have more money than you even need, so that feeling is somewhat lost. Gunplay feels slightly floaty" (can't really get my finger on what it is)

reviewText: There is truly only one way to say this: Bioshock maybe one of the best shooters ever made. The impact this series had on shooters truly is a wonder. Among the Call of Dutys and crappy Half Life rip-offs it's great when you find an original, story based shooter. That doesn't mean that shooters need to have a great story to be good, Doom barely had one and we still love it to this day, but Bioshock was just perfect. Although Bioshock 2 was a bit of a let down and wouldn't be my first choice of shooter sequel, Bioshocks glory came back in Bioshock Infinite and if I could recommend one of the Bioshock games, it would be Infinite. Still, this game is fantastic and I really do recommend you play it if you appreciate video games as an artwork and shooters as a genre. Bioshock gets a 9.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Bioshock is very good game with great storyline, art-style, decent graphics and interesting mechanics. It was fun playing it.
You are Jack who survived plane crash and found underwater city, way more technologically developed than other cities in 60's. He have to survive again but now there are mutants (crawling on walls, ceiling, teleporting, tossing fireballs or ice) and security system which could be used against enemies who would like to slice protagonist, it will only happen when the defense system is hacked (hacking minigame is simple/hard depends on how important/powerful turret you want hack, it can be easier by equipping skills/plasmids). You can also find so called sisters down there (little girls who are ADAM producers, it's very important currency to buy plasmids and upgrades as life and mana) you can save them, or harvest them (it will kill them obviously your choice :p ), those girls are almost harmless, but they walk always with Big Daddy who are strong as f*** and won't let you get to sister easily, you have to kill/destroy him, after that you're free to go).

original fight system (use weapons, or use plasmids/ spells which will freeze, burn, shock etc. enemy, very useful thing
weapons have 3 kinds of ammo (good with dealing humans, armoured enemies, or standard ammo)
hack defense system and wait for enemy annihilation ;]
you can also hypnotise Big Daddy who will protect you as little sister, but he can accidentally kill you if you get in his way ^^
great graphics of underwater city
great story
There are also cons:
fun feature, why protagonist can hold all that stuff and can't hold more than 500$ WTF? Comparing piece of paper or coin to huge weapon? Can't get it -.-
not enough ammo, it was hard to find it, sometimes had to fight with wrench and plasmids if I had mana, there are a lot of shops but with money limit you can't accumulate cash for later and when you need ammo you have no $ or inversely full cash full ammo and you find 90$ can't get it" F****! It's like the game is teasing/taunting you "remember that nice shining 100$? it would be nice to have it now >:D "

reviewText:
I was skeptical at first, since I started the series with Infinite and ended up not liking that game. Fortunately I decided against my bias and purchased this one.

One thing I love about Bioshock, is the way it tells or rather shows you the story and events in Rapture. Infinite in my humble opinion felt way too scripted, and it bugged me, how often that particular game took away my control over Bookers' character. Bioshock instead opts for a different way of handling this aspect by letting me, the player decide wether I want to give attention to a cutscenes or not, what I really like. Bioshock also features a very engaging story, that might surprise you.

Despite a somewhat antique" Unreal Engine 2
recommended: providing incredible (and unsettling) setpieces. Unfortunately ragdoll and physic animations are capped at 30FPS which really makes them stick out like a sore thumb. The games' biggest problem however are the low FOV and the ridiculously low weapon FOV
hoursPlayed: which made me motionsick after 5 minutes of playtime. This can be avoided by using a tool called "Flawless Widescreen" which allows the user to customize both options. Irrational Games did a great job on Bioshocks artdesign which still holds up even to this date. The music and soundeffects are well done and provide a good atmosphere.\n\nBioshocks gunplay is alright. The player is given a rather large arsenal of weaponary and plasmids. The guns felt a bit too weak
voteText: which turned some enemies into frustrating bulletsponges. My favourites are the wrench and the shotgun
helpfulPercent: which I found useful for all situations they game would throw at me. Plasmids are integrated well into the gameplay and are lots of fun to use
votesHelpful: even though "Elektroshock" turned out to be a bit too OP (extremely handy for foighting Big Daddies).\n\nI do have an issue with the health system. Even with a full inventory of health kits
votesTotal: I happened to die alot because there is little to no feedback when you're low on health. The bar isn't visible enough due to its rather small size and is in my opinion badly positioned (upper left corner). It would have been nice if the player was given the option to customize the HUD to their likings.\n\nThe game happened to run very badly on my PC. It crashed alot
votesFunny: never saved my settings and featured horrid mouse acceleratrion issues. The DX10 features are responsible for Bioshock not working properly on newer machines
commentsCount:
I advise to set the game to DX9 (add "-dx9" to the start options). Fixes for this game can be found on the PCGamingWiki.

I had a lot of fun with Bioshock and can safely recommend it to anyone who like to play First Person Shooters.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText: Calling the setting a character has become a cliché but Rapture, Bioshock's underwater city, is not only a character: it's the game's main character. In my journey through the game I've found myself much more interested in discovering the city's secrets and history than advancing the main plot. It's Ayn Rand's special halloween episode and it's great. The gameplay is a bit clumsy and I felt that were too many clashing systems that don't quite work together well. Still, it's one of the best games from last generation and I feel everyone should give it a try.
