reviewText:
Get yourself in a world of lunatics, in a big dark creepy city fully built underwater.
Fight against insanity, claustrophobia, and  seriously crazy tern of events.

This is game has very good graphics for its age. A small but sweet amount of weapons and 2 types of upgrades for each.
Combine guns and special powers to burn your enemies, electrocute them, freeze them or fill them with holes from your specially crafted antiarmor bullets shot by a crazy looking 24-bullet revolver.

Get through the world of Rapture, survive, hide and use hack and stealth mechanics or go on rampage mode and destroy and fry everything.
Gather materials, craft stuff, research attack systems and special skills, upgrade your skills and weapons, choose your skills wisely and stay alive and sane no matter what.

Beware of the enemy. Well designed AI for its time. Your enemies will seak ways to get wet if you light them up, they will seak places to hide, they will try to get themselves healed. They will swarm around you if you are not careful. And make sure to use any tech available to your benefit (hack turrets and cameras and make them friendly).

There's no wonder why this game was so successful. Perfectly combine FPS action shooting with survival horror and a very good and interesting plot.


Totally recommended and keep an eye for a complete franchise pack bundle!

reviewText:
Finally got around to finishing this tonight, it really is worth all the hype and acclaim it has received since 2007. Even though I only played through it this week, it still had a lot of jaw dropping moments, great atmosphere and one of the most vibrant and interesting worlds to explore in gaming.

Rapture is a haunting and beutifal city with a tortured but fascinating past. The mutterings, screams and genral dialouge uttered by the Splicers adds a real element of mystery and creepiness to everything, and the 30's-50's music that plays on radios in game further adds to the story of a once grand, fallen city, while also introducing a new genaration to some truely great music!!!

The ''plasmid'' system is a great addition to the game and has inspired several other games since, including Dishonered! Plasmids allow for a nice change from gunplay, which while fun, sometimes fails to satisfy. Choosing two plasmids to survive at a time adds some nice stratergy to the gameplay. It also stops the game feeling like it is too full of bullet sponges.

The story has one of the most genuinely great twists in gaming, one I can honestly say I did NOT see coming, yet it didn't feel forced. The ingame audio logs are all worth listening too (unfortunely, background noise sometimes interfers with these and that is a problem) and add only more intriuge about Rapture's history.

I attempted to play this back in July, but for whatever reason, it didn't grab me. I picked it up again this week, and couldn't put it down until I finished. For whatever reason, I complety misjudged this game, I really reccomend you play this masterpeice.

reviewText:
Formal Rating : 9/10
User Rating : Superb plot,INSTABUY
Date of the review : 05/26/2014

Bioshock.Well,i played BI first and then i tried this one,and i can clearly admit that i enjoyed this one way more than Bioshock Infinite.Why?Strongest plot,strongest gameplay.I loved every second of my playthrough.I couldn't stop pressing F12,i took like 60 photos,because in every room,there was something interesting.A corpse,a painting,a quote,you know,these kind of things.Plus,this game got its creepy moments too.For example dead corpses which are not really dead,Or rooms with creepy stuff like,toilets with not-so-much-light,or weird statuary.Anyway,lets continue on the details.

Plot : 10/10
1960, and you're flying over the Atlantic Ocean. One mysterious plane crash later, you're floating in the water, apparently the lone survivor, surrounded by the flaming wreckage of the aircraft. But there's a lighthouse on a tiny island just at the edge of your view.Your only chance is to get there.and so you do.inside,you find a submersible called bathysphere,which only purpose is to get you into the void of the sea.You don't have a choice,so you pull the trigger,the door closes,and you get down...down..There you find a secret city,underwater,named Rapture.An underwater city created by Andrew Ryan,with her own rules,her own freedom.However,everything has gone completely wrong.The city is vandalised,destroyed,and deadly lunatics roam the paths of Rapture.Apart from the phreaks,little girls named ''little sisters'' who contain the corrupting substance called ADAM move through the city with their ''protectors'' ''Big Daddies'',some people with a huge armor.

Gameplay : 9/10
Character Customization.nope,i dont mean you can change your appearance,however,you can find ''magical powers'' which can be shot out of your fingers,elemental powers such as electricity,Ice,fire,wind,even BEES (no,not the bees).Those powers consume EVE(mana).You can use your powers to control your enemies against your other enemies,you can use them to gain control of machines such as turrets.
Also,you got a variety of purchasable talents,which variety from Engineering,Physical,and Combat talents.each kind of talents got a different use,for example there's a physical talents which makes you swing your melee weapon faster.You start with 2 slots for every category of talents,and you can purchase more from a Gatherer's Garden .
There are 8 types of weapons,1 melee,6 guns,and a camera,which doesnt deal any damage,however it is used to take photographs of your enemies,so you can learn more about them and find new methods of dealing with them.There are 3 types of bullets for every gun,the normals,the armor penetration ones (against machines and big daddies) and the Antipersonnel ones which are useful against lunatics etc. You are also able to find weapon upgrade machines,which will make your weapons more powerful.
You can hack vents,safes,or even turrets to help you defeat your enemies.There are 2 types of ''money'' the normal money,and the consumable ADAM which give you new powers or slots or even higher health.ADAM can be used on a different kind of vent,the Gatherer's Garden.You can consume ADAM from the little sister,by either saving them(you will earn less,however everytime you complete a series of 3 ''rescues'' you will earn a surprise),or killing them.Finally,You collect audio logs which help you understand more whats going on.

Graphics : 8/10
I cant say i went crazy about the graphics,however Bioshock got some nice atmosphere.

Controls : 8/10
Easy Enough,however at the begining i got a little confused.

Audio : 10/10
Incredible voice acting,making the game stick greatly with the plot.Great soundtracks,but the thing i loved about the audio,is the music which plays when you rescue a little sister.its both beautiful and cute.

reviewText: Never had the chance to play BioShock when it came out until I finally grab it on Steam recently. As far as horror sci-fi shooter goes, this one comes with a really intricate background and very good story telling. The world is absorbing and Rapture as an underwater city seems believeable with the ideology of a capitalist despot during the post WWII era refreshing yet sort of expected from that time. The content is awesome, but the controls is a tad bit clunky compared to modern FPS and the map is just horrendous to look at and use. Mind you, this was published around 10 yrs ago. The metascore on this one is accurate. A very good game indeed and great atmosphere with a compelling story. It is truly a worthwhile experience for anyone who is into sci-fi and don't mind a little bit of horror elements (not ghost, just biomedical mutants).

reviewText: Describing a bioshock game to someone is a very arduous let alone strange task. Telling them about the wonderful yet delapidated undersea city called Rapture, the megalomaniacal Andrew Ryan; creator of the city, the highly addicted (injectible) drugs that give you superpowers is a joy. However it continues, as you must talk about the addicted Splicers, the Big Daddies, the Little sisters, the numerous other characters you meet on your journey who have been affected by rapture differentley, the wonderful locations that are both interesting and dangerous. Or, you can just tell this friend" of yours to stop asking so many questions about the game and to play it for themselves.\n\n10/10 - very good game. Now play it; Would You Kindly?"

reviewText: A dynamic-ish single-player first-person shooter with role-playing games' elements, this game has a nice story underwater based on the '60s, inside a city built by man, which looked like it was an underwater haven...until, as the story tells, the ADAM was founded, which had the ability to manipulate DNA structures and give inhuman abilites, which corrupted it's inhabitants. My favorite part of the game is obtaining the ADAM, by fighting against the enchanced giants Bid Daddies (seen in the picture), and they're the guardians of the Little Sisters. Although I've played on the Hard difficulty, the easiest part of the entire game was the final boss.\n\nSo, 8.5/10 for having the ability of combining logically realistic weapons with inhuman plasmid abilities and gene tonics, to make combos. Big Daddies, which are splitted into Bouncer (drill guy) and Rosie (guy with rifle-ish nail gun), and their Little Sisters, but negative points for easy final boss fight and a play-once game (unless you like to combine different combos).

reviewText:
So, would you kindly let me share my thoughts  on this game with you?
(informative, objective and spoiler free)

- It is an older game, graphics is not great, but still pretty decent.
- You will get lost a lot. This may be +, since it is not as linear as most games nowadays, but it can get annoying.
- Voice acting is not very well made
- Subtitles are different than voice, so if you like to play with subs on, it can get confusing
- NPCs have too few lines they keep repeating, which can be annoying... I used to be an adventurer like you...
- You will save a lot

If you still keep reading despite those minor setbacks, here is why the game is awesome
+ The story, despite being confusing at first, will be explained throughout this game with a few awesome nad unexpected plot twists.
+ The world continues in newer games, that I recommend to play, too. So if you like this game, you have more to look forward to
+ The atmosphere is well made
+ The gameplay itself is great, and quite intuitive. The game mechanics are good, too.
+ You choose how to play - melee or ranged? Traps and smart play or full out assault? Kill everything you see or spare some lives? (this is slightly taken into consideration for the ending sequence)
+ I did not encounter any bugs or crashes, running on PC win7 64bit.

There is one problem with this game when you ALT+TAB that a lot of people complain about. It can get stuck in window-mode. However, this can be easily fixed by pressing ALT+ENTER once or twice.

So do I recommend this game? It is too old to pay full price for, but if it is on sale, yes, definitely. You will not regret it.

Now, would you kindly make the purchase?
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Most FPS's are bland slog fests, no fun, no colour, or vibrancy; just dull pieces of work. Bioshock, is able to capture the fun of running, and gunning your oponents down, as a game, and is able to succeed that as an art.

Game wise, fairly standard assortment of guns, early to mid 1900's themed. Interesting twist yes? Now throw in rag-tag modifcations to guns, a plethora of different ammo that does everything from explode on impact to cause massive electrical damage. Then throw in almost supernatural powers, with a wide variety of character augmentations, to help you adapt to the changing environment. Want to run at 500% speed hitting people with a wrench in the back that freezes them solid, and you can become invisable- Bioshock has that.

These augmentations to the self are not just a gameplay feature, they are a core feature of the games narrative. The game itself portrays a distopian underwater city, that, as you are forced to enter seemingly, without your own choice in the matter, forces you to see what has happened. It forces you to take on this role, and realise who the real villain of the situation is, who or what is the real monster behind sociatal collapse and anarchy. Everything in the game seemingly has a suitable purpose to back up a part of the narrative, and it works, because nothing is then ever out of place. The game is able to form a cohesive structure, that despite its debatable ending, creates a wonderful philosophical experiance.

There are those that this game is a dumbed down System Shock 2, or even a console port that is meant for lesser gamers. But until we look at games in their individuality, we cant see the shine each one brings to the table. Bioshock, as a single product is simply an amazing game, that is a must own for any gamer.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I'm going to get this out of the way and just go ahead and say that this is literally the best game I have ever played. Yes, I said it. I don't say that about just any game. I saw friends casually playing this game years ago, and I always thought the Big Daddies you see everywhere looked pretty cool, but I never considered playing it due to its lack of hype. When I saw all three games go on sale as a package for 15$ on the Steam Holiday sale I had to do some research, because who can beat three full games for 15 bucks? Upon reading I found that people were upset at Bioshock Infinite's lack of quality compared to its predecessors, and the passion people had for the first two made the deal seem irresistable. I bought it and was instantly captivated by the creepy and atmospheric city of Rapture. I have only just begun playing the second game, but this game here is a masterpiece. P.S., if you play this, SEARCH FOR THE AUDIO LOGS! You're missing half of the game's beauty and story/immersiveness if you completely ignore these recordings that are scattered about rapture.\n\nBUY THIS GAME.

reviewText:
Formal Rating : 9/10
User Rating : Superb plot,INSTABUY
Date of the review : 05/26/2014

Bioshock.Well,i played BI first and then i tried this one,and i can clearly admit that i enjoyed this one way more than Bioshock Infinite.Why?Strongest plot,strongest gameplay.I loved every second of my playthrough.I couldn't stop pressing F12,i took like 60 photos,because in every room,there was something interesting.A corpse,a painting,a quote,you know,these kind of things.Plus,this game got its creepy moments too.For example dead corpses which are not really dead,Or rooms with creepy stuff like,toilets with not-so-much-light,or weird statuary.Anyway,lets continue on the details.

Plot : 10/10
1960, and you're flying over the Atlantic Ocean. One mysterious plane crash later, you're floating in the water, apparently the lone survivor, surrounded by the flaming wreckage of the aircraft. But there's a lighthouse on a tiny island just at the edge of your view.Your only chance is to get there.and so you do.inside,you find a submersible called bathysphere,which only purpose is to get you into the void of the sea.You don't have a choice,so you pull the trigger,the door closes,and you get down...down..There you find a secret city,underwater,named Rapture.An underwater city created by Andrew Ryan,with her own rules,her own freedom.However,everything has gone completely wrong.The city is vandalised,destroyed,and deadly lunatics roam the paths of Rapture.Apart from the phreaks,little girls named ''little sisters'' who contain the corrupting substance called ADAM move through the city with their ''protectors'' ''Big Daddies'',some people with a huge armor.

Gameplay : 9/10
Character Customization.nope,i dont mean you can change your appearance,however,you can find ''magical powers'' which can be shot out of your fingers,elemental powers such as electricity,Ice,fire,wind,even BEES (no,not the bees).Those powers consume EVE(mana).You can use your powers to control your enemies against your other enemies,you can use them to gain control of machines such as turrets.
Also,you got a variety of purchasable talents,which variety from Engineering,Physical,and Combat talents.each kind of talents got a different use,for example there's a physical talents which makes you swing your melee weapon faster.You start with 2 slots for every category of talents,and you can purchase more from a Gatherer's Garden .
There are 8 types of weapons,1 melee,6 guns,and a camera,which doesnt deal any damage,however it is used to take photographs of your enemies,so you can learn more about them and find new methods of dealing with them.There are 3 types of bullets for every gun,the normals,the armor penetration ones (against machines and big daddies) and the Antipersonnel ones which are useful against lunatics etc. You are also able to find weapon upgrade machines,which will make your weapons more powerful.
You can hack vents,safes,or even turrets to help you defeat your enemies.There are 2 types of ''money'' the normal money,and the consumable ADAM which give you new powers or slots or even higher health.ADAM can be used on a different kind of vent,the Gatherer's Garden.You can consume ADAM from the little sister,by either saving them(you will earn less,however everytime you complete a series of 3 ''rescues'' you will earn a surprise),or killing them.Finally,You collect audio logs which help you understand more whats going on.

Graphics : 8/10
I cant say i went crazy about the graphics,however Bioshock got some nice atmosphere.

Controls : 8/10
Easy Enough,however at the begining i got a little confused.

Audio : 10/10
Incredible voice acting,making the game stick greatly with the plot.Great soundtracks,but the thing i loved about the audio,is the music which plays when you rescue a little sister.its both beautiful and cute.

reviewText: Never had the chance to play BioShock when it came out until I finally grab it on Steam recently. As far as horror sci-fi shooter goes, this one comes with a really intricate background and very good story telling. The world is absorbing and Rapture as an underwater city seems believeable with the ideology of a capitalist despot during the post WWII era refreshing yet sort of expected from that time. The content is awesome, but the controls is a tad bit clunky compared to modern FPS and the map is just horrendous to look at and use. Mind you, this was published around 10 yrs ago. The metascore on this one is accurate. A very good game indeed and great atmosphere with a compelling story. It is truly a worthwhile experience for anyone who is into sci-fi and don't mind a little bit of horror elements (not ghost, just biomedical mutants).

reviewText: A dynamic-ish single-player first-person shooter with role-playing games' elements, this game has a nice story underwater based on the '60s, inside a city built by man, which looked like it was an underwater haven...until, as the story tells, the ADAM was founded, which had the ability to manipulate DNA structures and give inhuman abilites, which corrupted it's inhabitants. My favorite part of the game is obtaining the ADAM, by fighting against the enchanced giants Bid Daddies (seen in the picture), and they're the guardians of the Little Sisters. Although I've played on the Hard difficulty, the easiest part of the entire game was the final boss.\n\nSo, 8.5/10 for having the ability of combining logically realistic weapons with inhuman plasmid abilities and gene tonics, to make combos. Big Daddies, which are splitted into Bouncer (drill guy) and Rosie (guy with rifle-ish nail gun), and their Little Sisters, but negative points for easy final boss fight and a play-once game (unless you like to combine different combos).

reviewText:
If you're wondering whether or not to buy this game, then the answer is this: YES, ABSOLUTELY !

Now, I don't normally like shooters and scary games, where your enemies jump at you out of the blue but the trailers and screenshots from BioShock have always appealed to me and I finally decided to go through with the purchase. This turned to be one of my best gaming-related decisions so far.
From the intro, the game had me captivated. I immediately loved the atmosphere of Rapture, with its amazing art-deco architecture, and various locations (after all years since its release, the game still looks great), I could almost feel how it must have felt to walk in the shoes of the protagonists. This feeling was further enhanced by the music... Ohh yes, the music. Nothing builds an eerie atmosphere better than hearing a pleasant old-shool song, played as if from a vinyl disc, while exploring a blood-stained, ruined city.
The game mechanics? Here, there is little to mention apart from the fact that it's a solid, well-balanced shooter with some RPG entwined in it. You;ll have plenty of weapons, plasmids and genetic upgrades along the game but when all is said and done, you will end up using your three favourites. Hacking mini-games get a tiny bit boring after some time, but you can easily skip some of them with the help of items found along the way.
As far as graphics are concerned, I can only say that Irrational Games made wonders with Unreal Engine 3 and even now, even with almost minimum level of details, the game looks great.
Storywise, as far as video games are concerned - it's a masterpiece. If you don't play BioShock, you're missing out on a great story. and that's notwithstanding the fact that after the main plot twist (somewhere aobut 3/4 of a game) the plot loses its momentum a little.

Quick summary of advantages:
+amazing design and atmosphere of Rapture
+great soundtrack (music and voiceover alike)
+easy to master, entertaining combat with many possibilities to take down enemies
+brilliant storyline and memorable characters
+the game graphics did not age much
Some disadvantages:
-rubbish map, unintuitive journal (although you won't use the latter too much)
-if you don't like it - can give you a jump sometimes
-only a few types of enemies
-some artificial limitations - money cap, no plasmid+weapon combo...

One additional thought. If you're anxious that BioShock might be too scary for your tastes: don't worry. Just pluck up the courage and force yourself through the first two locations (like I had to :D) and from there, it will go al lot smoother. There are much fewer scary moments in the further part of the game and when they do appear, you will be able to predict them with ease.
So, coming back to the start: play BioShock, enjoy the story. You won't regret it and the memory of Rapture will stay with you for long.

reviewText:
Most FPS's are bland slog fests, no fun, no colour, or vibrancy; just dull pieces of work. Bioshock, is able to capture the fun of running, and gunning your oponents down, as a game, and is able to succeed that as an art.

Game wise, fairly standard assortment of guns, early to mid 1900's themed. Interesting twist yes? Now throw in rag-tag modifcations to guns, a plethora of different ammo that does everything from explode on impact to cause massive electrical damage. Then throw in almost supernatural powers, with a wide variety of character augmentations, to help you adapt to the changing environment. Want to run at 500% speed hitting people with a wrench in the back that freezes them solid, and you can become invisable- Bioshock has that.

These augmentations to the self are not just a gameplay feature, they are a core feature of the games narrative. The game itself portrays a distopian underwater city, that, as you are forced to enter seemingly, without your own choice in the matter, forces you to see what has happened. It forces you to take on this role, and realise who the real villain of the situation is, who or what is the real monster behind sociatal collapse and anarchy. Everything in the game seemingly has a suitable purpose to back up a part of the narrative, and it works, because nothing is then ever out of place. The game is able to form a cohesive structure, that despite its debatable ending, creates a wonderful philosophical experiance.

There are those that this game is a dumbed down System Shock 2, or even a console port that is meant for lesser gamers. But until we look at games in their individuality, we cant see the shine each one brings to the table. Bioshock, as a single product is simply an amazing game, that is a must own for any gamer.

reviewText: I don't think I can say anything that hasn't already been said about Bioshock. The game is fantastic in all apsects: Story presentation, music, the enviroments, the diaries slowly feeding you information. Gunplay and plasmids form a strong FPS core without feeling overhwleming. Really, all I can complain about is that if I have to play one more ♥♥♥♥ing game of pipe dreams I will take a wrench to someone's face. But in the end, everything comes together to form something much greater than the sum of its parts: Rapture. When the Great Chain of Industry ties all of Bioshock together, will you have your hand upon it, moving forward, inexorably forward?\n\nWould you kindly put your hand on the chain?

reviewText: I first played BioShock on the 360 and hated it. Then I got my hands on the PC version, and I'm starting to see why people like it so much.\n\nThe world is a massive breath of fresh air from the done-to-death Middle Easts and Europes of the world. But that's not what's best about it. The atmosphere is simply amazing. It's a rare feat for a game to make me *feel* the world around the player, and BioShock does it. Add to that gameplay that's simple, but works rather well (apart from plasmids being a bit overpowered) and a pretty well-written story, and you have a recipe for success.

reviewText:
Okay, so when this game first came out I over looked it.

I was aware, but foolishly ignored it, until finishing Bioshock Infinite and finding I felt a need to check this out.

At first I thought, this looks a little dated, but how foolish and naive I was.

Even now it holds up, the gameplay is fun, the story is great and the characters are all weirdos.

You play a man who doesnt speak, who seems to be a puppet and not just to the strings of my controller.

You go around, shooting freaks high on Adam and freaks they are......my kinda people.

You go from objective to objective, loving the story and occassional you meet a Big Daddy.

They're big, tough, with a massive drill.....not a inuendo! Who protect a little sister, who's full of delicious Adam.

You're faced with a choice....after emptying your entire weapon load into Big Daddy...again not an inuendo.......pervs!

Bleed the kid dry for extra Adam or save her.

I chose to save her......what kind of monster would bleed her dry???........well, maybe next play through.

Whichever you chose, will lead to a different ending, such fun.

Overall a great game, one i've just played nine years after its release and I love it, bring on Bioshock 2!!!!

reviewText:
This game is great, easily my favourite in the series and one of my favourite games ever!

The gameplay is really fun and this is the most unique FPS ever.
Plasmids are these things invented on Rapture and are great fun there are fire, ice, bee swarm and posess, combat is mixed between these plasmids, machines you can hack to help you and your guns and other weapons.

It's set in the underwater city of Rapture and it is so beautiful even in the sate it's in. Splicers are people who got addicted to the plasmids and went crazy and you will see a lot of them throughout the game, just listening to them you can see how far gone they are.

The story is really amazing about the rise and fall of Rapture, there are audio tapes that are actually really interesting if you take the time to listen and the BIG DADDY fights are great, you are fighting these huge things with drills for hands that just want to protect their little sisters in their eyes, splicers want to drain the sisters EVE to use plasmids by killing them, If you're not prepared these can kill you in seconds.

The game lasts over 12 hours and not one part wasn't unique or frustrating.
I would give this a 10/10, this is still one of my favourite games ever. Everyone should get this masterpiece.

reviewText:
Bioshock is first-person shooter action game developed by Irrational Games, 2K known as Boston / Australia in 2007.

The game takes place in the 60s. The player, Jack survives a plane crash and reaches the underwater city Rapture found in decay. There he must fight against mutated humans and capture the substance called ADAM inside little girls called Little Systers that are defended by powerful Divers called Big Daddies. This substance will let the player acquire genetic improvements .

Bioshock was really surprising because it created a whole new world with incredible narrative. history is noteworthy . Despite maps are not huge, they have superlative art and there are so many things to do that you never get bored . Combat is frenetic, there are turrets and machines to be hacked that provide ammunition and resources , there are also hidden resources and tonics to search that provide a remarkable range of combat.

Instead of just owning guns, machine guns, etc. , we find tonics fire , electric rays, clouds of bees or many other forms of attack. This mixed mechanism was fairly new and fun at the time and it succeded on a very good game, Dishonored (2012), that took this concept and adapted it well .

The game has elements of stealth, survival horror and role. It also has an important political component simulating an ultra-capitalist alternative world in a city where there are no ethical dilemmas and took to end the arts , science and engineering , which led to its decline .

It is one of the top ranked games of all time . It has two sequels. The bioshock 2 showing an ultra communist character and Bioshock infinite that develops in an aerial city. In Bioshock infinite political, religious and scientific plot led to the end in a very elaborate story.

The game was released for Windows PC , PS3 and XBOX 360. The windows version required DirectX 9.0c API.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
ESPAÑOL
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Bioshock es un videojuego de acción en primera persona desarrollado por Irrational Games, conocida como 2K Boston/Australia en 2007.

El juego transcurre en los 60. El jugador, Jack, sobrevive a un accidente de avión y llega a la ciudad submarina Rapture que se encuentra en decadencia. Allí deberá luchar contra seres humanos mutados y capturar la sustancia ADAM de pequeñas niñas defendidas por poderosos Buzos llamados Big Daddies. Esta sustancia le perimitirá adquirir mejoras genéticas.

Bioshock realmente sorprendió, ya que creó un mundo totalmente nuevo con una narrativa increible. la historia es digna de destacar. Si bien los mapas no son enormes, presentan un arte superlativo y hay tantas cosas que hacer que uno nunca se aburre. El combate es frenético, hay que hackear torretas y máquinas que brindan municiones y recursos, hay recursos ocultos para buscar y los tónicos brindan una variedad notoria al combate.

En lugar de solo poseer pistolas, ametralladoras, etc, nos encontramos con tónicos de fuego, rayos eléctricos, nubes de abejas u muchas otras formas de ataque.  Este mecanismo mixto de combate fue bastante novedoso y diria que el muy buen juego Dishonored de 2012 tomó este concepto y lo adaptó muy bien.

El juego posee elementos de sigilo, survival horror y rol. Además posee un importante componente político simulando una mundo alternativo en una ciudad ultracapitalista donde no hay dilemas éticos y se llevaron al extremo las artes, la ciencia y la ingeniería, lo que llevó a su decadencia.

Es uno de los juegos mejor rankeados de todos los tiempos. Posee dos secuelas. El bioshock 2 que muestra un personaje ultra comunista y el Bioshock infinite que se desarrolla en una ciudad aérea y hay componentes políticos, religiosos y científicos  llevados al extremo en una historia muy elaborada.

El juego se lanzó para PC bajo Windows, PS3 y XBOX 360. La versión de windows requería la API DirectX 9.0c

reviewText:
Fantastic start to an amazing series. Gameplay quality is amazing and leaves an immense amount of replay value. I don't think there is one bad thing I can think about this game. I love how it just throws you into the game, you really just learn on your feet. There are so many combinations of weapons/powers that it fits nearly any playstyle and there will no doubt be one set that you will be comfortable playing with. The story of this is just simply amazing, it throws you into the story in such a beautiful way.
I also very much like that what you do will affect what can happen later, it makes it that much more interesting in my opinion.
10/10.
Forever 10/10

reviewText: A very good game. Pretty smooth gameplay, an interesting story with a few well done twists and, if you don't rush through it, the game can easily last over 8 hours. My few complaints are that less experienced  players (like myself) have to rely on Vita-chambers and constant healing if you play on harder difficulties and that the ending left a lot of questions unanswered but it was still an enjoyable ending. I recommend buying this if your looking for a nice story in a first person shooter. It is a must buy if it goes on sale.

reviewText: This game is an absolute classic with an outstanding story. Initially Bioshock has almost a horroesque feel but it quickly becomes an Action/FPS driven by your need to learn more about this crazy and breathtaking place called Rapture. There is a fair amount of exploration and dialogue to balance the combat and you owe it to yourself to play this game especially if you haven't had is spoiled to you yet since it is known for having one hell of an ending.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I LOVED this game! Just finished playing it for the first time, and I have to say, it was amazing. It's about 6 years old, but still thrills to the bone! Rarely do you find such a smart shooter with RPG elements, climactic storytelling and great voice acting. Danger lurks around each corner in Rapture, but you don't feel powerless, just in need of constant survival. I liked how the game forced you into being efficient with your ammo, and made you use each weapon for different situations. I also liked the way the plot unfolded, not with an overwhelming surge of information, but with pieces of the puzzle which made sense in the end. I can't believe it took me so long to play Bioshock, and I can't wait to go through the sequel! Buy it, It's cheap, It's great, It's creepy!

reviewText: Bioshock is one the greatest shooters ever. Period. The combination of amazing atmosphere, gripping and intriguing narrative, one of the best settings for any game I've ever played, and varied, fun gameplay make this a truly unique experience, and it has one hell of a great follow up in Bioshock: Infinite. As for Bioshock 2, you can take it or leave it. But seeing as I have Infinite on my Xbox, consider this my recommendation for both Bioshock and Bioshock: Infinite.

reviewText: This is a great game. Everything from the combat is fun and responsive, and exploring the dark and wet tunnels of Rapture is awesome. The enemies are great, from the splicers to the Little Sisters and their Big Daddy defenders. But I have only one serious problem with this game. The devs did not joke around when it came to ammunition. The game claims that I need to gather Adam from the Little Sisters, but with what? Those Big Daddies are very powerful. Taking them down chews through your ammo like nothing! . Finding ammo is so difficult, often I find myself constantly dying while sniffing around for health, money and ammo. At least your enemies don't regen health when you respawn. It makes taking them down so much easier. Buying ammo from the vending machines will drain your money faster than you can say Screw you Rapture".\n\nWhy is the wrench such a pathetic weapon? It does no damage whatsoever. Melee is important in games. I found myself dying countless times because I have no ammo for my other guns
date: and I only have the wrench. It does nothing
hoursPlayed: NOTHING! (except for freezing enemies
voteText: but I'd rather use the chemical thrower for that.)\n\nAnd also
helpfulPercent: what is up with the boring
votesHelpful: tedious hacking mechanics? Why do you have to connect pipes to get fluid to go from input to output. It's so boring and if you don't do it right
votesTotal: you lose most of your health.\nRegardless
votesFunny: a fantastic game. Great story and narrative. Shooting mechanics need a bit of tweaking.\n\nIf you want to start a fresh new series

reviewText:
I bought this title after completing Bioshock Infinite, and didn't really know what to expect...
Its hard to say how it compares though, it felt like a totally different game, but oh-so-familiar, thankfully.
If you have not played it, do not expect it to be any less intense, atmospheric, emotional, addictive or demanding a game as its successors. Ooops, I forgot 'arguement causing' - maybe just me and the wife on that score,(70+ hours, but I am not the fastest). It did take me a few hours to realise that you dont have to confront every 'daddy', as much fun as it was. Dohh.
If you haven't got/had it, its well worth trying the free demo, Im sure you will be going for the triple-pack after you do. I feel compelled to get  Bio2 now...   just hoping the wife thinks I am stuck on the first. Lol.

reviewText: Bioshock was released in 2007 and it is a masterpiece, if you haven't played by now (its 2015 come on!!!!) then you must take the dive below to Rapture.\n\nBioshock is one of my favorite first person shooters/Rpgs as its not only got a fantastic story and atmosphere, but endless amounts of replayablity due to the combination of Plasmids (basically spells" you shoot from your hand) and tonics at your disposal. The story contains many interesting ideas concerning the nature of Free will and Objectivism (think Ayn Rand's the Fountainhead or Atlas Shrugged) combined with immersive level and sound design. You honestly must pick up this game

reviewText:
Bioshock... Where do I start? A friend recommended me this game, and I wasn't sure about it. Looked iffy, but as soon as I started playing, I knew why he liked it so much.

First of all...

The story Is completely extraordinary and you play not just to have fun but to be immersed in the disturbing story of Rapture, and what happened to it. I used to play games just to have fun, but now I really focus in on te story, and this one was extremely well written. I don't want to spoil a thing, but all I can say is the story is truely amazing.

Second...

This game came out in 2007, but the graphics were pretty kickass at the time. I think 2k really did it right with the graphics. They even look good in present day 2015, so give 2k and the Unreal Engine some credit

Lastly...

The Gameplay mechanics were really good. I liked how the guns handled, LOVED The plasmids and how unique each were. Aiming was not hard, which was good because the ADS Wasn't that good and I usually hipfired. The HUD was well made and looked good too, and switching weapons I could do with ease.

Complaints? Well, I guess there's one. SO HARD TO FIND AMMO!! But that aside, this game is EXTREMELY FUN and I know you will enjoy every little second of getting drugged, killing little sisters, and getting mowed down by big daddy's.

11/10 <-- Not even overexaggerating, I love this game.

reviewText: This is a great game. Everything from the combat is fun and responsive, and exploring the dark and wet tunnels of Rapture is awesome. The enemies are great, from the splicers to the Little Sisters and their Big Daddy defenders. But I have only one serious problem with this game. The devs did not joke around when it came to ammunition. The game claims that I need to gather Adam from the Little Sisters, but with what? Those Big Daddies are very powerful. Taking them down chews through your ammo like nothing! . Finding ammo is so difficult, often I find myself constantly dying while sniffing around for health, money and ammo. At least your enemies don't regen health when you respawn. It makes taking them down so much easier. Buying ammo from the vending machines will drain your money faster than you can say Screw you Rapture".\n\nWhy is the wrench such a pathetic weapon? It does no damage whatsoever. Melee is important in games. I found myself dying countless times because I have no ammo for my other guns

reviewText:
I am starting to write reviews for the games in my library and I declare this one as my first.  I will divide my reviews into three parts and a comments section to keep things standardized.  I will do my best to give candid and brief reviews.

Bioshock Review

(Story)
Do you have a choice?  This is the question Bioshock asks.  The game takes place in 1960, in an underwater city called Rapture.  The city is falling apart as civil war rages among its citizens.  As a nameless protagonist (who winds up in Rapture due to an accident), you meet and help numerous people as you learn more about what happened to the city leading up to the war.  There are good and evil choices to make and multiple endings to the main story that reflect your decisions.  The dialogue is well written and voice acting phenomenal.

(Gameplay)
Bioshock is a first person shooter with most combat taking place in close quarters areas.  You alternate between conventional fire arms and powers called plasmids" that allow you to shoot electricity from your hand
recommended: etc.  The weapons  have multiple ammo types/firing modes/uses that are acquired through upgrade stations.  Likewise

votesTotal: health
votesFunny: and crafting supplies are acquired from looting or use of vending machines strewn about.  One mechanic the first two Bioshock games are known for is enemy research.  In Bioshock
commentsCount: research is accomplished through taking photographs of enemies and filling your research bar.  Every time you reach a new level of research
column16:
you gain a damage boost against that particular enemy.  Ammo can get scarce sometimes.

(Design)
The art-deco/1950's/1960's America decor are very well done here.  The advertisements

column21: and fire leaves furniture (and enemies) charred.  The sound design is excellent

though I have an issue when gunfire starts where sounds cut out due to everything going on.

(Final Comments)
As the first in the series

reviewText: I LOVED this game! Just finished playing it for the first time, and I have to say, it was amazing. It's about 6 years old, but still thrills to the bone! Rarely do you find such a smart shooter with RPG elements, climactic storytelling and great voice acting. Danger lurks around each corner in Rapture, but you don't feel powerless, just in need of constant survival. I liked how the game forced you into being efficient with your ammo, and made you use each weapon for different situations. I also liked the way the plot unfolded, not with an overwhelming surge of information, but with pieces of the puzzle which made sense in the end. I can't believe it took me so long to play Bioshock, and I can't wait to go through the sequel! Buy it, It's cheap, It's great, It's creepy!

reviewText:
I've never really thought much of this game. I bought it to give it a second chance. Let's take a look how good it was.

Visually the game is good. The environment looks fine, but models are rather strange. Sounds are average, but the game has some nice songs playing from jukeboxes, radios etc. which fits the setting.
Gameplay is quite awkward. Even though it has some good features (hacking, plasmids), the action itself doesn't work that great. Enemies run around like idiots, which makes them difficult to hit. You never have enough ammo, but you can buy that from vending machines. Weapons can also be upgraded, though effectivity of these upgrades is sometimes questionable. Sometimes the game tends to be frustrating, but mostly it's alright. But then comes one part where you keep losing your maximum health. It happens quite often, like every five minutes. Developers probably thought it was a good idea to punish you for exploring instead of rushing towards the goal to stop this health loss. They were wrong. Thankfully, you can explore what you missed later after you find a solution for this situation, and even your health gets back to normal.
And the last thing to rate - the story. Hard to say anything about it since you hardly experience it directly. In order to get information about Rapture's past events, you must collect tape recorders and they slowly, like pieces of puzzle, let you see the whole picture. It's an interesting way to tell the story. The story itself seems above average.

Even though it didn't get to the list of my most favourite titles, the game as a whole isn't bad. Rapture has a very original atmosphere and the architecture along with music makes the place feel alive. This game's weakest point is the gameplay, but it still is quite fun. Let's just hope the developers learned from some of their mistakes and polished the other two Bioshock games more.

reviewText:
Bioshock is one of those games you can't help but to put in a category all by itself. It is not just an FPS, it is a narrative driven game where the story will take center place, and where the gameplay just seems to be the addition to that same story.

I can't tell the plot without spoiling it to anyone, but I will tell you this, it is a story so good, with plot twists that will blow your mind, that at some point Universal Pictures was going to produce a movie based on it. The whole game world sucks you in, you explore an underwater city called Rapture, after your airplane crashes in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean... and literally nothing in this game, story wise, is as it seems. I was really impressed with this AAA story, and if you like games that are not just about blowing stuff up(which Bioshock also has in spades) you will be looking at your screen in awe as you reach the end of the game. The story is simply put, phenomenal.

Gameplay wise, Bioshock offers a lot of freedom. You have your standard weapons, like a machine gun, a grenade launcher and a Pistol, each with 3 different ammo types. This plays a key role in battle, as some ammo is more efficient in dealing with certain types of enemies. You also have access to a camera, allowing you to take pictures of your enemies to discover their weaknesses, and it is a really useful tool. On top of the weapons, you have Plasmids. Plasmids are genetically created abilities that allow you to deal even more damage to your foes. You have Winter Blast which freezes your enemies which you can then dispose of with a shotgun blast for example, Electro Bolt which deals electricity to your enemies and hostile machinery, and quite a few others. The plasmids are what makes your approach to battles more fun. You can use them in any way you see fit, and this is what truly makes the combat in this game stand out. You have near infinite possibilities to dispose of your foes, and combined with your tonics, (upgrades that allow your character to get stronger and allow certain actions in the game a lot easier) you can become a true killing machine.

The AI in the game is quite impressive as well, with enemies running away when hurt, and looking for health stations to heal. These are some of the most challenging enemies in a video game I have ever encountered, and they will keep battles fresh and exciting.

There is so much more I could say about this game, but the essential is this: Bioshock is one complete game package. The story is amazing, the gameplay is perfect and revolutionary, the music fits the action nicely, and even the graphics are really good, for a game with a few years. Bioshock is in my opinion, one of the best games ever made, and for the price you pay, you will be getting a game experience you will never forget.

The Good

-Amazing Story, it will mess with your definition of morality
-Gameplay is fine tuned to perfection
-The Plasmids offer a freedom in combat that is uncommon in FPS/RPG hybrids
-Combat requires a cautious approach due to the ammo types in all weapons, simply point and shoot won't get you far
-Art style is phenomenal, the city of Rapture has a very Art Deco feel to it
-Characters in the game you actually care about(for the better and the worse)

The Bad

-Nothing I can think of, it is really close to perfection

9.5/10

reviewText: All the elements of a great game come together here to make Bioshock.  The graphic style is highly creative and distinct from other games.  You are surrounded by an early 1900s feeling with music from the era and architectural elements of the era as well.  The characters are absolutely nuts in a bio-enhanced way and they aren't too stupid either.  They run away to get health, sneak up on you by crawling on the ceiling.  It's actually quite creepy because of the atmosphere and the characters (friend and foe) that you meet through your journey.  The story isn't wonderful throughout the game, but the beginning and the ending (or rather endings) is rather powerful and rewarding.  Check it out, I had loads of fun, though its not for the squeamish, especially when it comes to harvesting little sisters.

reviewText:
Well... Where do I start?
The story starts with you, on a plane which somehow crashed into the sea and near a lighthouse.. It seems you're the only one that survives the crash and having no choice, you went inside the lighthouse and found a bathysphere.. Looks good enough, when you came down and found out that you were going to an underwater city called rapture where at first glance looks like an utopia, but hides a more sinister background.

Until here, I feel that the game follows the traditional line of FPS games. I have to admit, the graphics, music, and ambience was spot on. While those are factors that helps to improve game experience, I myself gave a higher emphasis on great story and plot rather than just aim and shoot.

As the story progresses, you will make choices such as deciding whether to (Spoiler) harvest or save the little sisters. Either one of those choices would impact the gameplay in a way and also (Spoiler) the ending as well. Nevertheless, as you progressed, you realised that what you perceived as the truth... might not be the right one after all.

After a quite lengthy process to reach what I thought was the end, instead I was given the shock of my life (Yes, that came out of nowhere). If you paid attention, you could see it happening, but you never thought it would be the crucial factor! Then came what I think is the weaker part of the game which are close to the end.. The boss battles was suprisingly not that difficult and the ending.. Well, even though I am glad my choices are correct, for some reason I wanted more (probably I hope I would get more explanation in Bioshock 2 and Infinite).

To be honest, I've heard of bioshock but never had the chance to play it until it was on sale (3 games for 13$). But after I played it, this game basically was an eye-opener. I had played many FPS games and not one game, have such amazing combination of all the factors that made the game not just great, but also potentially I could call a cult classic.

The game also introduced the music nicely, which opened my music sense to old songs from the 40s and 50s. Just like GTA opened my ears to spanish, classical, rock, rap, hip hop, and country music, this game allows me to listen and appreciate songs that baby boomers or traditional generations listen to.

All in all, I would give this game 9.4 / 10. This was that gem, that rare find in the sea of mud where contrary to popular belief, FPS games can also have amazing storyline and plot while having (during its time) a unique combat system.

This is easily one of my top 3 games of all time (which might change as I haven't played 2 and Infinite + the dlc!)


Now, would you kindly buy and play this game?

reviewText: All the elements of a great game come together here to make Bioshock.  The graphic style is highly creative and distinct from other games.  You are surrounded by an early 1900s feeling with music from the era and architectural elements of the era as well.  The characters are absolutely nuts in a bio-enhanced way and they aren't too stupid either.  They run away to get health, sneak up on you by crawling on the ceiling.  It's actually quite creepy because of the atmosphere and the characters (friend and foe) that you meet through your journey.  The story isn't wonderful throughout the game, but the beginning and the ending (or rather endings) is rather powerful and rewarding.  Check it out, I had loads of fun, though its not for the squeamish, especially when it comes to harvesting little sisters.

reviewText: This GAME!!! I shied away from it for a long time as I detest most shooter type games feeling that good suspense and horror is based on story and powerlessness of the main character.... But I was wrong! Not only is this game thick with well written themes, the gunplay is actually fun and doesnt wreck the rest of the game by consuming it with points, getting kills, or other such nonsense. The main character survives a plane crash only to find himself in some sort of underwater 'utopia' built by a man of science and industry. But as our main character discovers quite quickly, things have gone very wrong down in Rapture and he will be lucky to get out in one piece. Beautifully rendered using Art Deco motifs and music from the 1950s, this game is imaginative, brilliant, fun and I honestly cannot think of a single problem with it. It plays smoothly and without a glitch on my 300$ Del laptop. If you have not had the pleasure of discovering this game, do yourself a big favor and get it! Absolutely awesome~ 10/10 for game play, writing, graphics, sound and overall feel of the game in general.

reviewText:
A classic that I've never played before it's steam release and I'm here to say it's still worthy of most the praise it gets.
I'll keep it short.

GOOD
+Story is fantastic. Many hours of gameplay for a single player game. Even has replay value.
+The FPS elements are great. Using different guns and abilities to take out your enemies doesn't get stale.
+The RPG elements aren't perfect but can really change the way you play, especially when you start upgrading.
+ Even though through most of game the tension is high and it can be downright scary at times, it was never grotesque or resorted to jumpscares to shock you.
+ Difficulty modes. The game might be a bit overwhelming at first but is actually rather easy when you get used to it. But being able to increase the difficulty on subsequent playthroughs solves that problem.
+ Though the visuals might have aged somewhat, I got totally emersed in them.

NOT SO GOOD
- Controls aren't optimal and is part of the overwhelming start. Switching weapons, powers and ammo doesn't get smooth until you learn to just deal with it.
- The Hacking minigame, like in most other games, is too boring and occurs way too frequently. Almost every camera and turret in the game needs to be either hacked or destroyed to progress. And since conserving ammo is quite a big deal, hacking is the best choice but also the most boring one.
-Though survival and conserving your ammo are elements of the game, expect to blaze through on easier difficulties after you get used to the enemies and such. (Big Daddies are Big Babies, no really)
- The final araes of the game take a looong time. This might be a good thing to some, but it feels stretched and a little disjointed from the rest of the game. Making the ending overall a bit weak compared to all you've done to get there.

So step right up and get yourself a ticket to Rapture, because this game is totally worth playing! Especially if you've become a fan of the Bioshock series because of it's more recent installments!

reviewText: After having played this game the first time on the Xbox 360 and not paying attention to any of the story and finishing the final bos first try with a controller I thought this game was all hype. After having replayed it and this time actual paying attention, BRAVO! This was an outstanding game. The twist got me as if it was my first time playing this game. I already knew one twist, but the main twist got me like it should have the first time. Playing this game with a mouse and keyboard is definitely the way to go. Using a controller was just too slow to aim with and trying to hit splicers was a right pain in the ♥♥♥. That being said with the mouse I was able to clean house! The boss was still just as easy as it was with a controller, but I knew going in that the boss was a bit of a let down.\n\nThe many unique things about this game is what sticks with me the most. The plasmids giving you a super power is interstingly done. It changes your DNA and you need ADAM to splice yourself up more and get more powers. The setting is one of a kind. Not many would venture to the bottom of the sea and put a giant city in the name of freedom from all forms of Parasites." The story
recommended:
is fantastic. I never would have guessed the things I found out had I not played it again.

Even after all these years the game still holds up and is an instant classic. Now I understand completely. For people who want to play this and are having problems with the game crashing open up properties and open launch options. From the put type in -dx9 and it shouldn't crash while you play. You will also notice that the animations and ragdolls are at 30FPS. If you go online and look for bioshock physics unlocker it will fix that for you.

So overall for this game I am rating it a 9.5/10. I would give it a perfect score

reviewText:
You play as Jack (I had no idea this was the protagonist's name until I read it later) who never talks except for one line at the beginning intro. Your plane crashes next to a light house and you, for some reason, enter and explore Rapture.

The game has too many bugs and crashes. If you look deep into Google enough, you'll probably solve them. But it's a little frustrating when you have to keep trying to find solution to all the crashing.

The gameplay is really plain. It's your average shooter in a singleplayer game except you have some magic called ADAM. I found that a lot of the ADAM skills and other passive skills were not needed. I really only focused on just using guns, but that's just my playthrough of it. I felt the ADAM skills were only needed to stun enemies for a second.

The real reason why I'd only recommened this game is for the story. A lot of times I was anxious and paranoid for any enemies that might be crawling around, but I also felt sad for them. I kept feeling depressed after hearing the recordings that are left behind by previous Rapture citizens, the Little Sisters, and especially Sander Cohen. Out of all the games I've played, this guy was the craziest yet funniest villains I've encountered.

Overall: I have to give this 8/10
The whole time I've kept asking myself as the protagonist, Why the hell am I doing all this crap?" It's not until at the end when everything is revealed
date: which blew my mind. But there are too many pobrlems  with the crashing
hoursPlayed: and the mouse acceleration. However; I'd recommend this game for the lore and the environment. So would you kindly play this game?\n\nAlso

reviewText: This game is absolutely remarkable, In terms of the emotions you will experience, the plots twists you go through and the bold characters you encounter. It is essentially a morality game and so it forces you to make crucial decisions of which both effect you, the outcome of the game, characters around you and most importantly the power you will possess. Everything in Rapture is destroyed with mere intentions that just go wrong, leaving a dystopian world of chaos and greed. Ever character appears to be what they are because of rapture and their involvement with it, therefore, no one is technically 'evil' just flawed on different levels.\nProbably the standout element of Bioshock is the ability to modify your genetic make-up to develop new weapons and abilities - for instance, early on you gain the ability to fire lightning bolts from your hands, which can then be used on a simple level to stun enemies, rendering them more vulnerable to a solid whack with the wrench, or on a more strategic level to electrify water and take out multiple enemies, fry electrical devices, or enrage the Big Daddies and goad them into attacking other bad guys. Later on you can adopt more macabre plasmids, like the ability to fire swarms of bees, and passive skills like the power to tap into electronic devices.\n

reviewText:
Well... Where do I start?
The story starts with you, on a plane which somehow crashed into the sea and near a lighthouse.. It seems you're the only one that survives the crash and having no choice, you went inside the lighthouse and found a bathysphere.. Looks good enough, when you came down and found out that you were going to an underwater city called rapture where at first glance looks like an utopia, but hides a more sinister background.

Until here, I feel that the game follows the traditional line of FPS games. I have to admit, the graphics, music, and ambience was spot on. While those are factors that helps to improve game experience, I myself gave a higher emphasis on great story and plot rather than just aim and shoot.

As the story progresses, you will make choices such as deciding whether to (Spoiler) harvest or save the little sisters. Either one of those choices would impact the gameplay in a way and also (Spoiler) the ending as well. Nevertheless, as you progressed, you realised that what you perceived as the truth... might not be the right one after all.

After a quite lengthy process to reach what I thought was the end, instead I was given the shock of my life (Yes, that came out of nowhere). If you paid attention, you could see it happening, but you never thought it would be the crucial factor! Then came what I think is the weaker part of the game which are close to the end.. The boss battles was suprisingly not that difficult and the ending.. Well, even though I am glad my choices are correct, for some reason I wanted more (probably I hope I would get more explanation in Bioshock 2 and Infinite).

To be honest, I've heard of bioshock but never had the chance to play it until it was on sale (3 games for 13$). But after I played it, this game basically was an eye-opener. I had played many FPS games and not one game, have such amazing combination of all the factors that made the game not just great, but also potentially I could call a cult classic.

The game also introduced the music nicely, which opened my music sense to old songs from the 40s and 50s. Just like GTA opened my ears to spanish, classical, rock, rap, hip hop, and country music, this game allows me to listen and appreciate songs that baby boomers or traditional generations listen to.

All in all, I would give this game 9.4 / 10. This was that gem, that rare find in the sea of mud where contrary to popular belief, FPS games can also have amazing storyline and plot while having (during its time) a unique combat system.

This is easily one of my top 3 games of all time (which might change as I haven't played 2 and Infinite + the dlc!)


Now, would you kindly buy and play this game?

reviewText: BioShock is more than just a normal first-person shooter. The combat system is innovative, the game design suits the late 1960s style of the story and the story itself is stunning. By combining classic shooter elements, short to long ranged weapons, and a lot of different skills this fps is quite innovative. The skills enable the player to develope his own playstyle, either forcing your enemies to fight each other, or being center of the combat and shock, burn or freeze them yourself, both is possible. In addition to this every weapon and skill is upgradeable at different vending machines. This brings me to another key feature of the game, hacking. Nearly every electronic device such as vending machines, safes, doors and security bots can be hacked. Nevertheless, the crucial element is the story. The story is set in the 1960s and takes place in the underwater city Rapture, where the player encounters different charackters, one being more crazy than the other. The game creates a dark atmosphere with moments of horror, which underline the plot. All in all, BioShock is still worth its money!

reviewText:
My Thoughts/About The Game  This game is beautiful. It's a masterpiece, and I will never forget the happy ending I got when the game was finished. I felt like I couldn't write a review yet until I completed the game. I was actually not going to buy this game since it is a horror game. However, I pulled myself through and I was having a hell of a time. This game is old, but the game feels like it's new.

Pros:
+ Amazing graphics
+ Multiple endings
+ Story is compelling
+ Have the ability to hack machines
+ Arsenal, loads of weapons
+ Controls are easy to use
+ Upgrade powers and weapons

Cons:
- Certain plasmids have unfair advantages
- Crashes due to Unreal engine, sometimes
- Big Daddies become easier to deal with later on because of weapons such as the chemical thrower. It gives unfair advantages
- Annoying bug that changes your settings back to normal when you changed them for your desire

In Conclusion  What I put in the cons is probably mostly false since I couldn't really find any bad reason to not buy this game. The story, the arsenal of weapons and powers are what kept me coming back to this game. I can't compare this game to Bioshock 2 and Infinite because I haven't played them. Finally,  I recommend  this game to anyone who is new or experienced into shooters.

reviewText: What can I say about one of the most thought provoking games created in the 21st Century? One of the Master classes of FPS, BioShock combines exciting FPS gameplay, with a tense storyline, and brutal social commentary. For years I had waited for someone to do a refutation of Atlas Shrugged by the radical nut Ayn Rand. Finally I have been given something of that caliber. One of my favorite aspects of this game is its use of the Art Deco movement to define the architecture of the beautiful Rapture. Art Deco is one of my favorite art forms and to see it in a video game is just brilliant. Ken Levine is a master storyteller who isn't afraid to get his hands dirty in the mud pool that is political commentary. One of the greatest art works of our generation.

reviewText:
BioShock. What can I say.

This game is without a doubt in the running for game of the generation. For years prior to this game, the industry had been slipping out of the fact that games must tell a story, and focused more on how they played and esentailly how much money they can make. Then along game BioShock, the spiritual successor to System Shock 2, a game which would change the way we tell stories in games forever.

Packed in with its superb story, comes a uniqe horror-esq experience that I have only felt in BioShock. The atmosphere in this game is so fantastic, you would believe a city could actually be underwater. BioShock correctly displays the corruption of a once bold empire, and the impact it has had on life under the sea. The main character, Jack, is shrouded in mystery for most of the game until it" happens...

10/10. The 6th entry in my 10/10 hall of fame. Play the game."

reviewText:
A great sci fi horror game.
Takes place in a utopian city gone sour with it's own
apocalyptic setting.
Instead of dealing with zombies or the infected you are
dealing with a more challenging enemy.
Denizens of this city mutated and turned mad by the use
of a DNA extract called ADAM.
These degenerate humans are called splicers in this game,
and have run amok and taken over this underwater world.

Great action,good graphics and some suspenseful moments.
This is a game that can challenge your ability to survive.
A great addition to the genre of survival horror.
Recommended for those who like to find themselves in
dangerous situations with challenging enemies.

reviewText:
Here it is guys, the king of First-Person Shooters

Pros
-Its Bioshock
-Atmospheric and deep (literally)
-BEST PLOT TWIST (debatable)
-Super powers (Plasmids)
-Tension builds up
-Big Daddies
-Has a moral system (spare or kill little sisters)
-Its not a military FPS
-Deep and thought out story
-Collectables (which are actually enjoyable to collect)
-Learn more about the story through reading old documents, posters on walls, hidden art etc
-Basically everything about this game

Cons
-Silent Protagonist (Well, only spoke once)
-Bugs (my sound for this game didn't work until I tinkered with the sound system)

This game is good, no not good, amazing. not amazing, spectacular. Basically this game is a Masterpiece. Just wondering why are you reading this review and not playing the best fps ever?

Final Verdict: 10/10
Rating: MASTERPIECE

reviewText:
After hyping up BioShock for a long time, expecting it to be System Shock 3. I was VERY dissapointed.

The gameplay felt dumbed down and there was absolutely no relation story wise (except for some similar elements).

So I stopped playing it, and left it for about 6 years (not even kidding).

I returned to it last year with a fresh pair of eyes, knowing it has nothing to do with System Shock and is it's own thing.

The gameplay was not as bad as I thought and is quite in depth. The enemies are varied and interesting. And a fair amount of weaponry is available to dispatch them. Each one can be upgraded and can be used in unison with plasmids and tonics to create deadly combos.

But where it really shines is the story, characters, setting, art, lore, concepts and atmosphere. It is AMAZING. It all comes together to make a truly immersive and terrifying experience. And should be considered to be an artistic masterpiece.

I can't recommend this any more. Play this in the dark with headphones and soak it in.

Edit:

However the ending leaves something to be desired.

reviewText: This game just oozes with atmosphere, it's brilliant. So is the storytelling. The graphics still hold up to this day and the sound is awesome. During the game you gain access to special powers and search for items, similar to RPGs. The powers are diverse and fun and switching between them keeps things fresh. The game manages to scare a few times in the beginning, but once you know what you're up against it pretty much stops being scary. Multiple endings give the game great replay value and it already is exceptionally long for a FPS. This should already be in everyone's collection.\n\n[Rating: 94/100]

reviewText: Bioshock is essential. It's categorically revered as one of the greatest games ever made, and while it has it's flaws (repetitive, not that fun combat, balance issues - both of which were fixed in the even better Bioshock 2) the overall experience is unforgettable. The underwater city of Rapture offers one of the most compelling and captivating environments ever brought into gaming, and the story offers twists and turns driven by some larger than life characters. This game is magnificent, you absolutely need to play it.

reviewText: It's the best First Person Shooter I've ever played. Bioshock was released in August 2007 and almost 10 years later it still manages to look and sound better than most modern games. When it comes to its story, characters and atmosphere, I don't think it's been done better before or after. From the iconic Big Daddies to Rapture itself, the entire mythology surrounding this game is a masterwork of science fiction and a watershed moment not only in gaming but in pop culture itself. I'm not sure there's such a thing as a perfect game but if there is, Bioshock should definitely be in the conversation.

reviewText:
I've played this game ALOT before it was available on Steam.

Bioshock is a great game with a great story. I do NOT recommend this game to anyone who expects it to be a run and gun game like Borderlands. Bioshock is a great Story-Driven game.

In this game you play as Jack, the only survivor from a plane crash in the Atlantic Ocean, You make your way to the underwater City Rapture which once was a beautiful city but many things went wrong.
Explore Rapture which once was a beautiful Utopia under the sea.

I also recommend the Novel from Bioshock, I'm not a reader myself BUT! I recently finished the book and it was amazing! It will tell alot about Rapture, from building the city to how it all went wrong, but more importantly, you will also KNOW who some of the characters are in the game from certain audio dairies, replaying the game after reading the book opens a new view on the game. 10/10
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is a piece of art. It's a masterpiece. However, the gameplay itself isn't what makes the game special to me. What makes the game truly amazing is the atmosphere of the world. The levels are so detailed. You can learn so much about the history of the world just by observing advertisements on the walls and listening to audio tapes scattered across the world. The story is so unique. The lore of this game is what's going to keep me coming back for more. There are many plot twists that will shock and amaze you. The gameplay isn't anything amazing or innovating. It's a first person shooter full of your normal: revolvers, machine guns, shotguns, grenade launhers. But the game also includes superpowers called: plasmids. These really keep the game fresh and exciting as you can do anything from emitting electrcity from your hands or using telekinisis to lift dead enemies and use them as a human shield. Overall, the gameplay is really fun and addictive and is a great complement to the amazing atmosphere, story, and world of Bioshock.\n\n10/10

reviewText:
I don't know how to write this review without giving out spoilers, but I shall try.

I bought this game after playing Bioshock Infinite, of course expecting the same beautiful visuals, story-line and characters.
Wasn't disappointed, but... since the city of Rapture is underwater as opposed to suspended in the sky, there were some stark differences, one of which is obviously the lighting and atmosphere, it's all so eerie and creepy, with a decent number of jumpscares.

The first 5-6 hrs of the game were an utter bore to me, I was struggling with my Eves and First Aid Kits, kept running out of ammo, it was tricky to switch between the plasmid and your weapon mid-fight, and the freaky atmosphere wasn't doing anything to make me feel better. But after that, it was all uphill, I started seeing the reason why I bought this game in the first place, the story picked up, it was paramount to solve the current mission and move on to the next ASAP.

Gameplay wise, it is decent, but what really is the heart and soul of the game is the story and the morality of your choices. I chose badly, thinking there was no other option and will always be haunted by my choices. The ending was quite emotional and a real kick in the gut.


The game did crash a couple of times though...

The Bioshock franchise has a knack for brilliant story-telling, and now, would you kindly buy the game and see for yourself. =)

reviewText:
I'll entertain you with a short story.

I owned a PS2 when I was a kid. I only owned a couple of games, MLB '06 and a couple Guitar Hero games. Not a lot of real game games, y'know? I built my computer, this glorious, 1600 dollar computer that I put my heart and soul into. I got Steam, and my first sale was the summer sale this year.

I saw the entire Bioshock franchise on sale for amazingly cheap prices, and of course I scooped them up. Bioshock feels like my first real game. It was my first real foray into gaming, my first real game. It's fantastic. The maps, the enemies, the narrative, the social commentary on the state of the gaming industry...it's all fantastic. It deserves its place on the lists of greatest games of all time.

reviewText:
I played it circa 2008 on my Xbox 360 and didn't even get past the first area of the game(also I played with hardest difficulty at that time) and continued on to other games at the time like Fallout 3/Mass Effect which are way more better imo.

On PC I got it few years ago in a humble bundle and It sat along with part 2 and Infinite(which I bought last sale) until yesterday when I tried playing it... I just finished Bioshock 1 today, and will play 2 shortly, although I played at easiest difficulty and finished in about 6 hrs.

Rapture is boring for me, the game kinda gets repetitive and I can't really relate myself to the games atmosphere, everything feels alienating. 1960s tech, impossible underwater city, super genetic manipulations, and characters that are badly deformed, etc.

Playing the game seems more of a chore than an actual enjoyment to justify the $1 I spent on the humble bundle. nevertheless, I'll still play them. Looking forward to Infinite, which judging from trailers and gameplays, looked better to my tastes.

Although honestly If it wasn't in my game library I would have just looked up at some youtube videos showing the whole story.

I give the game 6/10. Still recommend
