reviewText:
I remember when BioShock was almost upon us in 2007. The spiritual successor to System Shock 2 made by the same people who made System Shock 2? I had to own this. I had read the reviews again and again, watched every trailer and ordered my collector's edition with the Big Daddy model that managed to arrive at my house undamaged and then the big day arrived. I installed it, fought with the SecuROM DRM and was immediately having sound and graphical problems because this was 2007, the time Windows Vista was making lives a misery for people around the world, drivers for sound cards were generally crap and games made for Windows Vista sometimes didn't work well with XP and vice versa.

But now it is officially the future and going back to this game on a nice beefy PC was an amazing experience, I had forgotten how good this game was and how close to System Shock 2 it was and, if you like that game then you will most certainly like this.

BioShock is a First-Person Shooter with horror and stealth elements set in the year 1960. You are on a flight to an unknown destination when all of a sudden, the plane ends up crashing somewhere in the Atlantic Ocean and you are the only survivor. You make your way to a lighthouse in the distance only to find, not sanctuary and rescue from the near-death experience you just survived, but the gateway to a mysterious underwater city built by one of the most libertarian antagonists you will probably ever see in a video game.

When you arrive, the city is in a state of chaos and decay. The majority of its residents are dead and the few that have survived have either gone insane or are just trying to survive and find a way to leave. A lack of maintenance is causing the city to slowly fall apart and flood. You will have to find some way of getting back to the world above.

You are not completely defenceless however, you soon learn of a mysterious substance called ADAM and how it can be used to alter an individuals genetic code from scratch. Plasmids are powers which you can acquire that will give you many different abilities such as the ability to set foes on fire, freeze them on the spot in ice, throw heavy things with telekinesis and even summon a swarm of killer insects!

From the very beginning, the game does a phenomenal job of creating an amazing world for the player to explore with a really nicely done Art Deco style and presentation. The game also feels very reminiscent of the Fallout series. The music and some of the artwork you'll see will definitely make you feel a little Wasteland nostalgia deep inside.

Every game so far made by Ken Levine has had a brilliant story to it and BioShock is no different. Like System Shock 2, you'll find Accu-Vox voice recorders lying around the environments you explore that are made by the citizens of the city. They will tell most of the story and give you key information about what exactly happened to the residents in the city, how it all started to collapse and how to progress through the dangerous world ahead.

The first hour or so of the game is quite linear, guiding you around perfectly crafted set-pieces and environments to get you used to what exactly is going on, what everything is and does and who your friends and foes are. The game opens up fairly quickly with non-linear levels and the player is then free to explore any area they can get access to. The environments are nicely varied and very detailed too; you will explore many different locations along your journey such as theatres, parks, hospitals and gardens and you are free to go back to any area you have previously been to.

The game is extremely atmospheric. A large part of the game's atmosphere comes from its amazing lighting and sound score. The sombre music and orchestral stings do an amazing job of creating a unique sense of fear and tension that had not been seen any any game before it.  The water effects were also, for the time, an incredible accomplishment and something that had not been seen since Half-Life 2. Different objects have different levels of buoyancy, water leaks from the ceiling and walls, doors that are holding back water from a collapsed walkway are bulging and warping due to the pressure and it all adds up to a constant lingering reminder of where you are and what is happening to the city. The game also includes a fair amount of superbly crafted jump scares and is good with messing with your head right until the very end of the game.

BioShock's game mechanics largely copy System Shock 2's albeit with a few corners cut off; the game doesn't have a deep role-playing system like System Shock 2. Shock 2 has a full RPG system with character statistics and skills and those skills were needed to determine what you were good at doing. In BioShock, you can hack any machine, use any gun and use and plasmid right from the beginning. The only thing that comes close to any sort of RPG element comes from the equippable plasmids and tonics you find and earn. You have a limited amount of slots for them which means choosing what you want to be able to use against your enemies at will require some forward thinking.

BioShock also allows for the use of different ammo types in weapons, you have your standard kind of ammo that's quite plentiful but not really good or bad against any specific thing but guns can have armour-piercing rounds for tough opponents, anti-personnel rounds for dealing quickly with squishy human type enemies, proximity mines for sealing off passageways and many other kinds of things. You will need to choose the right ammo type for the right opponent in order to conserve that precious ammo.

And now, it's time to talk about the faults, yes it has faults but they are somewhat minor. Hacking, whilst always useful, is the most bizarre and tedious mini-game that they could've made. You have to reveal tiles on a grid that conceal different sections of pipes and then re-arrange those pieces of pipes to form a system that can get a slowly progressing body of water along from its starting point to its finishing point whist avoiding security and alarm nodes which are also hidden under those tiles. It can be fun at times but after the 50th time you do it, you may find it becoming tedious. You have the option to just pay money to hack things anyway if you're feeling lazy. The game also pauses whilst you hack so if a camera is just out of reach, you can jump, hit the hack button and hack away whilst seemingly floating in mid-air!

Also, they went and added some more plasmids and tonics as downloadable content but they fell into the trap of breaking immersion by telling you in game that those new goodies are downloaded" when you go to buy them and thinking the player wants access to them with as little effort as possible
date: therefore setting the price of these new goodies to just 1 ADAM each! It wouldn't have taken much effort to sensibly price them to match their original counterparts. A slightly missed opportunity to make your plasmid buying decisions a tiny bit more demanding.\n\nThe final area of the game is a pain
recommended: having to go through a tedious section with really slow pacing is probably the lowest point of the game. The boss fights for the game are
hoursPlayed: for the most part
voteText: exactly like fighting normal enemies but they just have more hit-points. The game also wants to hold your hand all the way through. It will constantly remind you to press keys to reload and press keys if you are stuck and need a hint.\n\nBioShock is an incredible game to play and I'm glad I went through it again as I was reminded just how much of a good game it was. It's an artistic and technological masterpiece that has aged really well and is a blast to play from start to finish. Just be sure to go through the options
helpfulPercent: turn off Vita (Respawn) Chambers that eliminate all challenge and play on at least Normal difficulty to have one whale of a time!"

reviewText:
Bioshock:

Positives:

+ There is a really engaging story in Bioshock with a twist that you won't expect. Audio logs which supplement the plotline can be found by exploring the environment and are a welcome addition. The game is set in the underwater city of Rapture and follows two men who struggle for power - Andrew Ryan, leader of the famous Ryan Industries and Frank Fontaine.
+ There are quite a few weapons that can be upgraded, like crossbows, shotguns, pistols, the Tommy Gun, grenade launchers and a chemical thrower which fires liquid nitrogen, napalm and electric gel.
+ A key part of Bioshock is the use of Plasmids, genetic abilities which can freeze enemies solid, incinerate or electrocute them. Unleash a swarm of killer insects or create a decoy target to draw fire away from you. There's many options here.
+ To add greater complexity there are tonics which improve your skills in countless ways. Physical tonics add healing benefits and eve restoration (eve is required to cast plasmids), engineering tonics are crucial to hacking safes, door combinations, gun turrets, vending machines and cameras. Then you've got combat tonics for physical damage resistance.
+ The characters are interesting, the shooting is great, basically it's fun which is the most important pro.

Mixed:

~ Only about 15 hours of content for this FPS, which is not much (played on medium difficulty and didn't really have any issues). It's not the worst I've seen but clearly it's lacking in gameplay longevity.
~ Graphics are not bad considering the age of this game. Average.
~ Somewhat linear game. It is not open-world and there are no side missions, it's strictly one area to the next. With that said, it's forgiveable since the developers have put some sort of effort into hidden areas and locations which aren't essential.

Negatives:

- Very poor map design, confusing to navigate and find out where to go for your next objective.

Overall Score: 8/10

Very much recommended!

reviewText:
Fantastic game.
In Bioshock you play as Shaun Dingus on his way down to Glass City. But just as his plane is about to land at the local Glass City airport the main man of glass city, Paul Ryan, changes his mind and throws the ocean at him. At this point Dingus is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and decides to infiltrate Glass City himself and kill every single person inside of it.

Once inside Glass Town, all kinds of adventures await. There are superpowers, little girls, and you even get to shoot washed-up spacemen who just got back for retirement. Plus, if you collect all the Jinjos in every stage, you unlock a special secret near the end of the game.

Near the end of the game you get to meet Paul Ryan himself, who tells Dingus it was all just a prank and asks him to join him for a round of golf. When Dingus beats Paul, Paul gets so mad that he runs into the wall and dies. It is later revealed that Dingus isn't actually Dingus, but instead Dingus' brother Roy who was cybernetically enhanced to beat Paul in golf. Now with his only mission in life fulfilled, Roy goes and wins the lottery and becomes a millionare.

The ending really got to me because I was like: Dang

reviewText: Bioshock is an atmospheric game that creates a dark beautiful world. The overall story might not satisfy some, but as you continue to play the game you fall in love with Rapture and why was created. The underwater city is not chained by morality and as a result you will encounter disturbing imagery that captivates you at the same time. It is a great shooter that has RPG elements, which increases the variety of gameplay options and allows you to experiment. The choice you make in regards to the storyline also provides another reason to play the game again. Even if the ending is lackluster, the tension and awe you feel throughout the game is extraordinary. Bioshock delivers an enjoyable and immersive experience that should not be forgotten or missed by any avid gamer.

reviewText:
I have played this on The Xbox 360, and just recently picked it up on Steam, the first two games were on sale back in December, and how could I NOT pick them up they are some of the most fantastic first person shooters I've played since the Doom 3 days. Today in gaming first person shooter just means Call of Duty Clone or something of that flavor, and it's kind of depressing most people think that.

This game you don't have infinite ammo, you have to worry about your health. The environment feels terrifying sometimes to the point where I just can't play the game, but that's cool, because I like to be scared out of a game from time to time.  Though I do wish you had more freedom around Rapture. It's just go here do this and onward. Sometimes you just want to putz around, but there's no way to do that without not progressing in the game.

If you haven't played this game before you NEED TO PICK THIS UP NOW AND PLAY THROUGH IT!

reviewText:
'A man choose, a slave obeys.'
These words remain resonant in my head after playing Bioshock. Its one of those games which makes you question humanity and whether us as humans are men or slaves.
The gameplay, whilst a little clunky, is satisfying and varied, although the Telekninesis plasmid is ridiculously powerful. The atmosphere is incredible and Rapture really sucks you in as a world. The story is also fantastic, however I found the ending to be slightly lackluster. (I harvested the sisters)
Overall then, Bioshock is a masterpiece. The game holds you and doesn't let go until you force yourself to put the controller down.
9.8/10

reviewText: While on the surface it might look like little more than a very pretty first-person shooter, BioShock is much, much more than that. Sure, the action is fine, but its primary focus is its story, a sci-fi mystery that manages to feel retro and futuristic at the same time, and its characters, who convey most of the story via radio transmissions and audio logs that you're constantly stumbling upon as you wander around. All of it blends together to form an interesting underwater world that sucks you in right away and won't let go until you've figured out what, exactly, is going on in the undersea city of Rapture.\nMy only disclaimer is that playing this at night is a heart attack waiting to happen. I'm telling you: those splicers, man...

reviewText: So after a five day binge play of the BioShock franchise, here are my thoughts about the game that started it all.\n\nFor those who live under rocks, this game started two 'kinda big' controversies. One being the idiotic 'this disk will self destruct' one time instal that the original PC version came with, and the second being that the game was overtly pro-Communism and and anti-Libertarian. Before I get into the right/wrong for this game, let me address both the reasons for uproar. Firstly, video game companies have proven to be nothing but greedy a-holes that we enjoy licking. Born of the mentality that when you buy a game, it's not your property, it still belongs to the game company, we've been gifted with same day DLC, on disk DLC, the war on Game Stop, and still paying $60+ for digital titles. This was one of the first attempts to wrestle ownership of a game away from you and keep it firmly in 2K's hands, and you just pay for the privilege. Kinda funny for a game that seems to extol the virtues of the Communist manifesto that nothing belongs to the individual, to actually do just that! Clever marketing maybe? Anyway, as to the second bit of trouble, the game does go out of it's way to show that the Libertarian idea of free markets and minimal government involvement leads to mass suffering.... until you reach the end of the game. No spoilers, but as the game goes above and beyond in blaming the Great Chain" for Rapture's destruction

reviewText:
(Low playtime due to playing boxed copy)

It is no exaggeration to classify BioShock as a videogaming masterpiece.

Weaving together themes of objectivism, transhumanism and political ideology, BioShock builds a coherent narrative that is engaging and thought provoking. On the surface it is a first person shooter with RPG elements, presenting a unique fusion of traditional weapon based combat with plasmid powers to take down enemies. But when the subtle thematic elements, inspiring art style and intriguing characters are taken together the result is a highly memorable exploration of human beings and being human.

What is the role of government? What are the rights and responsibilities of the individual? What does it mean to be human?

In attempting to address these questions Andrew Ryan built an underwater city to serve as a fortress where unbridled creativity could flourish from the worlds intellectual and cultural elite. The city is called Rapture, and Andrew Ryan is its king. He envisioned an objectivist utopia whose citizens would be free to pursue self-interest, built upon free-market enterprise. He encouraged his citizens to abandon religion in favour of the will to be great. He encouraged scientists to conduct research without restrictive ethical guidelines; artists to express themselves without the fear of censorship; businesses to trade free of regulations.

The result is a society that quickly becomes fractured down class lines amidst a background of greed, corruption and an economic recession that hits when construction of the city ends. Rapture disintegrates, its citizens splitting into factions - Sophia Lamb espouses an altruistic collectivist philosophy that sets a background of discontent as she discredits Ryan in several prominent debates. Atlas leads the working class poor, bitter about the empty promises offered to them in Raptures halls. Andrew Ryan maintains the loyalties of most of Raptures wealthy and powerful elite. Civil war breaks out, made all the more horrific by the militarisation of recent 'plasmid' technologies which were initially introduced to enhance human abilities and provide novel solutions to first world problems - Light a cigarette from your fingertips with Incinerate! A plasmid by Ryan Industries."

The player enters this world accidentally
date: finding the smouldering ruins of a once great city being picked over by genetically enhanced 'splicers'
recommended: as well as the little sisters that gather ADAM from their bodies. This substance is used as a currency for the purchase of plasmid abilities

In order to survive the player must defeat the daddies to obtain ADAM from the sisters. In doing so they must make difficult choices and live with the consequences.\n\nThe story

reviewText: BioShock is a classic, for good reason.  It has aged well and continues to be just as powerful as it was when released.  I envy the first-time player, as the plot twists will still amaze you, but even the repeat player can quickly find themselves lost in the incredible atmosphere of this game.  Mechanically, it is an above-average FPS that not only provides multiple options for how to handle situations, but each of those options is actually perfectly viable.  The opponents are interesting and Big Daddies still make me dirty my pants.  The last hour of the game is less than perfect, but even that is still better than most other games out there.  Well worth playing, again.

reviewText:
Finally finished this game, and it's one of the best shooters that I have played in a long time, specially considering that it's 7 years old.

The mechanics and abilities are very well done, and even if I didn't feel the need to use all the plasmids, the ones that I used were very well balance, even if some of them were overpowered, the same with the weapons. The resources in the game, like money and munnitions, were far and few at the beginning, making you think how to approach certain situatios, but at the end there was so much of everything that you could go guns blazing everywere and never run short of anything.

The plot was excellent, some of the plot twist you could see coming a mile away, but there were some really great surprises, and with the aditional information found in the tapes makes it one of the more memorable storylines in the last years.

All in all, I would recommend this game to any fan of shotters or games with a great plot.

reviewText:
It's been 6 years since this game was released. And tonight, I finally finished it. If you simply want a thumbs up or down - it's a big thumbs up!

Starting off in that plane, crashing to Rapture and going inside...man...what a feeling. And the messed up things you find inside... The Splicers, plasmids, Ryan, Fontaine, Atlus, etc. etc. It's all so well written and brought to life through the ageing Unreal Engine 2.5.
Some of the hacking really does provide nice little detours on the way, e.g. hacking cameras to spot enemies instead of yourself. Or hacking machines to give you cheaper items. And there's plenty to hack along the way! Nice little touches that make for a richer experience.

The downers? Well, I played without seeking a solution to the mouse acceleration and that made some things difficult. Apparently there is a fix, so, if you're gonna play this game, get that fix! Other than that, there's little I could possibly pick up on. It all works so well that it's hard for me to find a real flaw. Maybe the EAX audio stuff is a teeny bit broken at this point! lol Honestly, that's all I've got.

Overall, I gotta say, I've been a fool to avoid this game for so long. The journey your character takes, along with finding out the history of Rapture, is brilliantly done. And at the end, I walked away happy with my choices and the overall outcome (There are three endings). It may be a fairly old game now, but, damn...it plays better than a lot of stuff released today. You owe it to yourself to play this game!

reviewText:
Words cannot describe how amazing this game is.

But I will try.

Firstly, the story. The characters have amazing and well thought out backstories, the story of the game itself is compelling and will constantly twist, without it feeling overused. I don't often like to play a games campaign more than once, but this is definitely an exception. After completing the game once it gives you a completely different viewpoint the next playthrough.
Next, the weapons. None are particularly overpowered, and everyone I know who plays has a different favourite gun. They all suit different playstyles in different ways incredibly effectively.
Finally, the enemies. Loads of people think Big Daddies are invincible, or that the splicers would be too easy. Yet no, the game is perfectly balanced, Big Daddies can easily be beaten with a little thinking and Splicers are tweaked just enough to make them a slight challenge in large numbers.
Overall, this game is probably my favourite of all time, just buy it. There isnt a 96 metascore for nothing! I also highly reccomend the other 2 aswell.

reviewText: BioShock is a classic, for good reason.  It has aged well and continues to be just as powerful as it was when released.  I envy the first-time player, as the plot twists will still amaze you, but even the repeat player can quickly find themselves lost in the incredible atmosphere of this game.  Mechanically, it is an above-average FPS that not only provides multiple options for how to handle situations, but each of those options is actually perfectly viable.  The opponents are interesting and Big Daddies still make me dirty my pants.  The last hour of the game is less than perfect, but even that is still better than most other games out there.  Well worth playing, again.

reviewText:
Loved this game. It may be a few years old, but I couldn't tell from the graphics, which were still stellar. The story is extremely well done and engaging throughout- you will be searching for every voxophone and going down every side corridor to learn more.

Gameplay was also very fun- I played on Normal difficulty, which was challenging enough that I was never bored, while not being hard enough that I was frustrated. There weren't too many weapons to choose from (and to be honest some just didn't seem that effective compared to the standard Wrench) but I never found myself bored or distracted by that fact. Same with the Plasmids (basically, magic spells)- I almost always used the standard Electric Shock, but the others were still interesting and the gameplay forced you to use some of the other Plasmids in order to unlock secret areas or find hidden voxophones which advanced the story.

In sum, I would give this game an 8/10, with a recommendation for people who want an engaging story to go with their gameplay.

reviewText: This is a game worthy of praise. Bioshock is an example of a game that does not get repetitive in story. The setting itself is quite original from most shooters to start with. This game also gives you a diverse range of ways to kill opponents and a lot of back story, which is not common for most videogames. The fighting is fairly simple, with a flair for dramatic deaths and a way to make quick allies. The fighting is very satisfying and new players can catch on quickly. The story is so well written and dialouged with excellent voice actors that you are drawn into it. The silent protagonist makes you sympathize with his situation from the very start. The plot twist could not have also been better delivered. The Plasmids also make fighting enemies an extremely creative process, I dare say an art form. No two people may choose the exact same plasmids as another person, making this game very fluid in its ability to offer many ways to combat enemies in the game, not just limited to run and gun. Stealth is also an important component in this game when you are low on ammo or are surrounded by numerous enemies and big daddies, often outting you at a disadvantage. The layout of the levels are also very condusive to the atmosphere and the the music score was flawless. The last thing is that though this game may not be known as a horror title, it definitly has its moments that frighten you. This game is so well made that I would dare recomend it even to people who only like playing sports games. This game whould be labled in my opinion the best well rounded, because of all its attributes and pluses. I can't even really think of anything bad or negative to say, though then again, I never really say anything bad because I always look for what is best in a game. This game has my full confidence. If you are planning to buy, you should have full confidence that this game will give you the best time for your money. ever.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
BioShock is simply a masterpiece.

Pros: Graphics, Sound, Story
Cons: Controls, Gameplay

In 2007, BioShock presented one of the most beautiful and immersive worlds in the history of video games.  Everything meshed together so well, from the 60s style advertisements to the tinkle of the water on the crumbling floors.  The worst of humanity: selfishness, vanity, pride; met the best: ingenuity, passion, perseverance.  And the story naturally unfolded.

Sometimes, controls can be wonky and the combat could be a lot smoother.  Big Daddies can be very, very difficult to take down.  A certain escort mission is rough, but most escort missions are rough. Despite these shortcomings, BioShock is a game that manages to mix art and philosophy, and ask some big questions.

Would you sacrifice your humanity?"

10/10"

reviewText:
I'll never forget how incredible the first 30 minutes of game play was to me when i first got this. It had been out for a few months by this point and incredibly i had heard nothing of the game other than a vague report from a friend it might be alright (months before it's release). The events of those first thirty minutes (trying not to give anything away here) quite literally had me sitting on the edge of my seat mouth open wide. It wasn't just the story, it was the immersion effect it had on me. Had a console version back then and played it through a few times.

Now owing a pc version i decided to have another wander through Rapture. Boy am i glad i did! Lots of things i remembered, plenty i forgot. But what really had me was how well it has stood up to the test of time. I just plain enjoy everything about this game. Graphics and animations are beautiful with creative level design coupled with dynamic lighting that really gives the sensation of being on the bottom of the ocean, even if it is a little dated. Yes there is a bit of backward and forward grinding to be done mission wise, but the story/tapes you uncover along the way i feel are worth it and help the overall story. All in all Bioshock is a classic and a fantastic 25-35 hour adventure.

My Specs:
i7 4770
16GB Ram
GTX770 OC (4GB VRAM)

Thanks for reading! :)

reviewText:
Had problems getting it working on Win7. Steam should really have a notice stating exactly where players can get the information to get the game up and running. However in the end I got it running.

Probably my 4th-5th play through, I knew the story, I knew what was going to happen, and yet I was still immersed in the world of Rapture, I found out more and found new areas, and I was still terrified moving around the environments as the lighting, shadowing and sound really add to the tension of being alone in an underwater city.

Probably one of the best games of all time. Story is amazing like the rest of the series, gameplay/gunplay is meh, but has some pretty neat mechanics. Enemies constantly refill areas when revisiting which can be annoying, time consuming and a waste of ammo. Big daddies are great mini-boses but it can be annoying when you die half way through a battle as the little sister may have gone back home meaning the whole fight was pointless.

I would kindly ask anyone who doesn't just play FPS games for multiplayer and scoring headshots against nazi zombies to buy the game.

reviewText:
Bioshock: System Shock 2... again. 8/10

Seriously. The twist is the same, the characters are the same, the mechanics are the same (but simplified). Just felt like pointing that out... ON TO THE REVIEW!

+The graphics look good to this day, with great water effects.
+Amazing voice acting (the villain, as in the villain in the last quarter, is kind of over the top, but I think that that was intentional)
+Good golden oldies soundtrack
+Fun gunplay (mostly)
+The plasmids/Psi powers/Vigors add a really fun dynamic to gunplay (even if half of them are useless)
+The Art Deco designs are awesome.
+Rapture is just a really cool setting.
+Incredibly well written (you gotta love Andrew Ryan's rants, especially the ones nearer to his end. A man chooses...")
+Great commentary on the nature of gaming narratives that I won't spoil.

-The final act of the game is just so awful. I feel like the game would have been twice as good if they had just ended with the twist reveal.
-The Tommygun is so boring to use. This is a huge minus as it is the weapon with probably the most common ammo.
-Speaking of which
date: the survival horor elements just feel token. At the beginning it is effective
hoursPlayed: the lack of ammo just makes the game tedium. It is difficult to feel any sort of tension when there is no consequence to death (until the finale).\n-The final level of the game is an escort mission. A buggy escort mission. Enough said.\n-The final boss is awful. The developers (in an attempt to add tension presumably) made it so that you cannot save or respawn while fighting the boss. If you die
voteText: you are thrown into the main menu. The boss has three forms. All of them will kill you in two hits. This is not how you raise the stakes.\n-Both of the endings (this being an early 360/PS3 generation game has a pointless and simple morality system) are awful and abrupt. You are either a saint or the devil (despite the fact that the game actually tells you that the "EVIL" choice is good... but whatever)."

reviewText:
Just finished Bioshock, and oh what a game. This game is superbly made in all aspects, including soundtrack, gameplay, graphics, story and overall fun, atmosphere and replay-ability.

Firstly soundtrack, and it is simply sublime. I can and have listened to it while doing work or studying, it is that good. Not only is it awesome without the game, but when added to the game it increases the atmosphere ten-fold. Gameplay is fluid and very entertaining, with very awesome boss fights. Most people did not like the puzzle feature, but honestly I didn'd mind it. Yes, it did get very repititive, but it never took away from the experience overall. The graphics are fantastic, and the artsyle was fantastic and well backed up by the music which matches perfectly. Story is absolutely fantastic. It is interesting and complex, and contains messages and themes that make the game thought-provoking and insightful. Plasmids have a large variety and make the game a lot of fun. You can rarely shoot bees out of your hands to aid you in battle in many other games. As i spoke about before the atmosphere is created by the artstyle, story and soundtrack, which makes you feel amazing while playing. The game has multible endings and tonnes of content, which means I will defnitely return to rapture ASAP.

Overall Bioshock is a fantastic game that is an easy 10/10 for me.

reviewText:
Words cannot describe how amazing this game is.

But I will try.

Firstly, the story. The characters have amazing and well thought out backstories, the story of the game itself is compelling and will constantly twist, without it feeling overused. I don't often like to play a games campaign more than once, but this is definitely an exception. After completing the game once it gives you a completely different viewpoint the next playthrough.
Next, the weapons. None are particularly overpowered, and everyone I know who plays has a different favourite gun. They all suit different playstyles in different ways incredibly effectively.
Finally, the enemies. Loads of people think Big Daddies are invincible, or that the splicers would be too easy. Yet no, the game is perfectly balanced, Big Daddies can easily be beaten with a little thinking and Splicers are tweaked just enough to make them a slight challenge in large numbers.
Overall, this game is probably my favourite of all time, just buy it. There isnt a 96 metascore for nothing! I also highly reccomend the other 2 aswell.

reviewText: If Half-Life pioneered FPS horror, Bioshock perfected it. The distopian city of Rapture is a screwed up place. Everyone has gone mad and the enemies are extremely scarey. On the down side, I felt that Bioshock felt was too repetitive, it had a great story, but there were too many big daddies. I think that fighting big daddies should be an event and a boss fight. There should not be three per level. Overall, Bioshock was a revolutionary game and it presented a great story, some of the levels felt too mundane and big daddies were not treated as bosses, but as common unconvenience.

reviewText:
The best FPS game I've ever played, and I've tried HL2. Everything about it - everything - is brilliant. Rapture is magnificent, one of the great settings ever devised in gaming. It is a glorioius masterpiece gone mad, turning into one of the creepiest gaming experiences I've ever played.

The combat is fantastic. The sheer variety of styles available to you is simply staggering. 8 different guns, 8 different plasmids, hacked turrets, hacked security drones...it's amazing how many choices you have in the way you fight.

Of course, the real selling point is the story. It is a philosophical masterpiece with a stunning twist in the middle that practically knocked me off of my feet. The depth and complexity involved is incredible. There's a ludicrous amount of content available for you to find, whether it's through in-game dialogue, audio logs, incidental dialogue from splicers, or simple exploration of the rooms.

The only disappointing part of the game is the boss battle at the end of it, which is disappointingly generic and easy. But it's a minor quibble when put up against the mastery that makes up the rest of the game. A 10 of 10 game if I've ever played one, and you owe it to yourself to play it.

reviewText: While I most likely won't be playing more than 100 hours on this game, I still recommend buying it on sale. It's a great game. It's got fun graphics, a wonderful storyline, and the actual playing is just tons of fun! (Spoilers Ahead) The powers are fantastic, being able to control electricity, fire, ice, and several others is incredible, and ties in perfectly with the storyline of the game. There is a big twist at the end that, while a bit obvious when you look back, is still entertaining and shakes things up quite a bit. It's a bit creepy, a lot of fun, and worth buying. I only say on sale because while all of those things are true, it lacks a certain amount of replayability. You could go through it twice, maybe three or four times, and each time beat it in roughly fifteen hours, but the choices don't change up much. Replaying it becomes experimenting with what weapon combinations work best for you. The surprises of the game will probably fade, but it's still worth the buy!

reviewText: I'll admit, I missed the Bioshock bandwagon when it stormed into the scene in 2007 and shook the foundations of videogames forever. Only when the fantastic Infinite came out was my curiosity once-again piqued and I decided to go for the Bioshock/2 Steam sale and experience for myself the artistic masterpiece in the haunting dystopia of Rapture. However, my experiences were slightly underwhelming, and only then did I realize the game - while changing the face of videogaming's artistic merit - has indeed aged, and not for the better.\n\nTo be fair, I went in knowing all the twists and turns that in 2007 rocked gamers everywhere. I knew Rapure, I knew the massive Shaymalan-esque twists, and I knew the shoe-horned morality system and derogatory good and bad" endings. And that really did cripple my experience; since Bioshock's main selling factor was the general surprise of it all
date: seven years later the "gotcha" moments have dwindled into insignificance. That isn't to say there weren't unexpected beautiful and haunting moments: one of my personally favorite videogame moments ever was murdering the first Big Daddy to the backdrop of Billie Holiday's "God Bless the Child" soliloquizing the background
recommended: it created an aura of innocence that only punctuated my immoral actions
hoursPlayed: and was all the more powerful because of it. Speaking of which
voteText: and expectantly by now
helpfulPercent: the soundrack is probably one of videogaming's best - from the beautiful vocals of Holiday to the soothing strings of Django Reinhardt to the chilling "I am Rapture
votesHelpful: Rapture is Me" score
votesTotal: my journey was never a bland one
votesFunny: almost atmospheric enough to distract me from the archaic and outdated gaming mechanics.\n\nYes
commentsCount: this game is first and foremost a first-person shooter
column16: and here it fails most signicifantly. From the frustration of having to switch between my guns and my plasmids (which 2 and Infinite later fixed)
column17: to the ease of revitalizing myself with little penalty
column18: to the unacceptable lack of aiming down the sights. Even by 2007 these mechanics were outdated
column19: and while they were largely distracted by the overall atmosphere
column20: as a gamer seven years later I can't help but be frustrated and underwhelmed. We now also have to deal with the generic "fetch quests
column21: and the tired trope of meeting a potentially interesting person, having to collect and deliver X-amounts of items to them, then just having them poetically offed or - shocker - turning on you. This does does drag on a bit, then you enter the game's fantastic climax, and then you're back on the same boring track until you get to the infamous and bland final boss.\n\nAs a gamer, never will I ever discredit Bioshock as a forefather of its time and one that has elevated games to a level of esteem that without Ken Levine we simply wouldn't have. But also as a gamer, I cannot look past its glaring flaws in mechanics that other titles such as Deus Ex and System Shock 2 already overcame (and at least a decade earlier). As a retrospective gamer in modern times I see Bioshock as a title that has aged poorly, especially for a first-person genre that even now has hit a creative roadblock. In my opinion, Infinite is a far superior title that has successfully married gameplay with presentation. But if you look at Bioshock as an experience, not a game, with beautiful moments and one of gamings greatest settings, then yes, it is the esteemed and magnificent title we all know and love.

reviewText:
Bioshock is an action game, as you have not yet experienced. On the bottom of the sea awaits the utopian city of Rapture, torn by genetic civil war. Discover an incredible, but deadly in the Art Deco style, you will find impressive technology and meet fascinating people. A complete arsenal of weapons available to you - from simple revolvers to rocket or flamethrowers. Resist the rules of nature. Use plasmid injections to modify your DNA and unlock superhuman powers.

Biological modifications for your body: Fire electronic lightning from your fingertips or brood in your own body killer hornets that you can hunt your opponents behind.

Everything is a weapon! Your environment, fire, water, and even yourself - thanks to various gene manipulations.

86/100

reviewText:
In my highly valid and valued opinion this game is by far the scariest and most atmospherical game ever. Also it made me interested in the story behind rapture and its inhabitants.

I am Andrew Ryan and I am here to ask you a question:
Is a man not entitled to the sweat of his brow?

No, says the man in Washington; it belongs to the poor.
No, says the man in the Vatican; it belongs to God.
No, says the man in Moscow; it belongs to everyone.

I rejected those answers. Instead, I chose something
different. I chose the impossible. I chose...

Rapture.

10/10

reviewText: Decent game, bad PC port. The screen seems stretched regardless of FOV/Resolution setting. And the mouse aim is just... off. I can't tell if it's an acceleration issue or something else, but it's impossible to aim here. The controls generally are pretty ♥♥♥♥ poor, and there's a lot of graphical issue, notably particle effects cause some heavy hitting FPS despite the game looking old. The game its self is highly overrated. There are two different enemies in the game, big daddy's and your run of the mill human enemies. Kind of a letdown considering how creative the setting is. The actual weapons are okay but they feel really clumsy, if it weren't for the health bar I wouldn't be able to tell I was doing any damage. It's an okay experience best left to consoles. 7/10.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Like its predecessor, 'System Shock 2', 'Bioshock' is not a fluid experience. Whilst 'System Shock 2' is infamous for being an unforgiving and disorientatingly deep game, 'Bioshock' becomes too easy. It is possible to completely break the combat with the right combination of plasmids, tonics, and weapon upgrades (which are far too abundant). The game attempts to merge the 'Half-Life' shooting system with the roleplaying elements of 'System Shock 2' and sadly both styles do not mix. The 'Half-Life' model is intended to be balanced and dynamic, whilst adding customisation to this ruins that balance and narrows the players choice.

The 'moral choice' system remains pointless, since rescuing Little Sisters gives you plenty of Adam already. There is no need or reason to harvest them unless you get some sick pleasure out of seeing little children being evicerated - in which case, you deserve the awful ending you get for following that path. Not that the other ending is much better. In fact, the last section of the game is awful.

Which is a shame because whilst the gameplay is flawed, the story and enviroment are strong enough to warrant a reccomendation. The beautifully rendered enviroment tells a story in itself, and the audio logs add a welcome 'second layer' to the narrative. Just like its follow-up, 'Biosock Infinite', the best parts of the game are usually spent roaming the enviroment absorbing it all. The opening sequence may be one of the best in gaming (play the demo if you think I'm exaggerating) - which makes it all the more infuriating that the ending is such an ill-fitting anti-climax.

reviewText:
This is an absolutely brilliant game. My friend set me up for it, at first I wasn't really interested in buying it, but after he urged me to get it, I decided to give the first one a shot.

Now I'm personally not a big fan of any scary stuff so the first hour of the game scared the crap out of me (I know, I know...). But after playing for maybe 1 and a half hours tops I was completely hooked. I would think about the game while going to bed. The story is just plain brilliant and how the story is based on and revolves around several ideals, it's just fantastically done.

What I really loved about the game is that it's different from other shooters. In mainstream shooters you get guns and you shoot the ♥♥♥♥ out of the other guy and if you die you respawn with full ammo. In this game you have to be careful with everything you get because it's really easy to run out of money, which means no ammo. You constantly have to keep yourself stocked. Now of course you can find ammo lying around, but in all fairness it's really easy to run out of ammo and money if you're not paying attention to it.

I'm a sucker for upgrading things, so the upgrading feature of the game was probably what I loved the most. Not only can you upgrade your guns, but also your abilities. Man don't get me even started on those! They way they set it up so you can play it in your own style of prefrences is just fantastic. However I was a little concerned with how difficult it is sometimes to change stuff around to have the abilities to your own liking.

All in all, I recommend this game to everyone who's a fan of shooters or just creepy stuff in general. I know it's not really catigorized as scary"
recommended: it scared the crap out of me sometimes. After playing through it
hoursPlayed: I didn't hesitate to get number 2 and I also plan on getting Infinite when it goes on sale.\n\n8/10"

reviewText:
A single-player only, story driven First Person Shooter with an imaginative setting and story. It took me 29 hours to beat it on hard, first try, 100% completion. If you're not as... thorough... as I am, then you ought to be able to beat it in 15-20 hours or so.
I'd rate it pretty highly.

BioShock puts you in the shoes of a survivor of a mid-ocean plane crash. With no where else to go, you swim to a nearby lighthouse but... why is it there?

The game was designed for consoles so this is a PC-port. If you use a controller, you'll be in good hands. If you prefer the mouse and keyboard, then you'll probably want to fiddle with the .ini files in order to fix" the mouse control. To do this
hoursPlayed: navigate to your documents folder and find the "AppData" folder. It is hidden so make sure you are showing hidden files in Windows. You're looking for the folder: [username]\AppData\Roaming\Bioshock\nIn there
voteText:
you'll find a user.ini and a bioshock.ini file.
In the user.ini file find/add the following lines: (you can change the MouseAccelThreshold to 1.0 if you'd like some acceleration)
MouseSmoothingMode=0
MouseAccelThreshold=0.0

In the bioshock.ini file find/add the following lines: (they appear twice each
helpfulPercent:
so make sure to set both to false)
CaptureMouse=False
ReduceMouseLag=False
DoubleBufferMouseLag=False

If the game ever crashes on you (which it will if you alt-tab or if you use the Steam overlay too many times)
votesHelpful: then these two files will be overwritten with a default file (bye bye custom controls =/ )\nTo circumvent this
votesTotal: make a copy of these two files after you set up your graphics/sound/control options. If the game crashes
votesFunny: relaunch it
commentsCount: close it
column16: and copy your backup files over the existing user.ini and bioshock.ini files to quickly restore your settings.\n\nAnyways
column17: once your mouse settings are good to go the gameplay is great
column18: and the story is engaging. If you haven't played this game yet then you're missing out. Have fun!"

reviewText:
Played it in one sit-in. The game was pretty hard on normal. Hard felt harder than 1999 mode on Bioshock infinite. I loved the level of detail, difficulty and the mechanics. the characters were unforgetable and felt very alive. even though the mechanics felt a bit outdated even for its time, I liked that it added character to the entire game. Sorta like what tank controls did for resident evil. the only difference is that Bioshock is actually playable. The enviroments tell a story without words and the tape recorders exapnd more on what may have happened before your arrival. Bioshock is an instant classic in my book.

Length: About 8-10 hours on normal.

10/10

reviewText:
All good things lead to the city.  The defunct city of Rapture, specifically, led by Andrew Ryan.  A spiritual successor to the System Shock series, Bioshock places you in an underwater dystopia filled with splicers and danger.  The main focus of this game is on the ideals that both made Rapture great and heavily contributed to its downfall at the same time.  If you take nothing else away from this game, always remember:
What separates a man from a slave?  Money?  Power?  No... A man chooses.  A slave obeys."

reviewText: Bioshock is by far one of the most different and coolest games I have played.  I found the world of Rapture to be really creepy and the monsters that I fought as well.  I thought the weapons selection was good and the add ons and upgrades really added spice to them.  I did find myself wanting to get to the end of the game about half way through.  Having to complete tasks in order to advance was just annoying and cumbersome.  When I finally did reach the last boss, he was so easy to beat.  I got all my weapons and ammunition loaded up and ready for the final battle.  The last boss was far easier than most of the monsters I fought throughout the game.  Overall, great game, really creepy, great weapons and decent story.  Every gamer should play this game at least once in their lifetime.  This will go down as a classic.

reviewText: I suffer with the no sound after plane crash problem (seems to affect most people using Vista or later), however I discovered that I do get sound after the plane crash (Win 8.1), but only via the headphone port on the front of my PC. If I could leave a neutral review as opposed to just recommend or don't recommend, I would do, as it's just about okay, but not awful enough to avoid. I tend to prefer conventional military shooters though, and this is a bit different. Each to their own.

reviewText:
Seeing the ridiculous amounts of hype, i could not wait to play Bioshock.
With its apparently mesmerising storyline and beautiful…well, everything. It seemed like it would be the perfect game for me...
The storyline, i must say is truly wonderful, an innovative idea that's extremely well thought out and executed. This is accompanied by the also stunning visuals and environment style which are perfect for achieving the grungy, dystopian and eerie style that’s so synonymous with the series.

Unfortunately, this did not make me impressed enough with the game enough to actually fall in love with it, or even like it slightly more than the average RPG.
The gameplay style is very original, making it more of a ‘real life gun holding simulator’ than an FPS. This was highly annoying at times unfortunately.  Although this style has it’s charms, its slightly more irritating than ‘fun’.  Plasmids are pretty damn awesome but after using them on your 5000th bot, they get very boring.
Which brings me on to my next point… It’s so damn repetitive. With the occasional plot point being the only thing that’s keeping you going, you battle through hordes of splicers again and again… and again…

Basically, the longer you play, the more bored you get. With one or two twists in the story line that re-activate your interest in the game occasionally, I can say… I was vey disappointed in the game.

It’s a beautifully made, artistic… boring game. Not saying it's bad, but its just quite boring at times.

60/100

BTW This is a good game, but during the middle of it? It's pretty damn boring.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I never write reviews, but I feel that BioShock deserves any words of praise that it receives.  I've played hundreds of games and BioShock stands apart in terms of the world that was created, the stellar narrative, the intriguing characters and enemies, and so on.  I put this game above BioShock Infinite (though that's a fine game).  Especially if you remain unspoiled, you need to play this game.  I have yet to encounter a world or story that I find as incredible as Rhapsody (I'd also recommend the Bioshock book for a followup to the game).

reviewText:
Guys.

Get this game. It has one of the greatest feelings for an adventure game! The feeling of excitement.

Even though the whole creepy factor is a bit lackluster, it's a really great game.
Probably the reason why that they made two more games for it.

The whole switching between the weapons and Plasmids (It's like magic but though gene splicing. I think I may now be part electric eel, volcano, blizzard, insect, etc. without losing my face.) is a tad awkward. Seems number keys for guns and Function keys for Plasmids wasn't enough. They learned their lesson later.

Though one thing I really appreciate is how they explain the whole situation through recordings you find in the depths of that underwater hellhole Rapture. It's so f*cking unique! I love it! It actually helps me understand what the f*ck is going on under there!

Poor Jack. Just keep going.

There is no God. Only Man.

reviewText:
Bioshock 1, the spiritual sucessor to System Shock and keeping most of the creepyness of its forefather intact. *SPOILERS PRESENT*

Lets talk about the first thing we see in the game, the Graphics, the game just oozes with atmosphere and detail, when you walk around rapture you can see how people would live their lives, theres no randomly placed gap which would make you wonder how people got over it or why its there its modeled in a way that you'll walk around a place the same way you would if Rapture was real, and not falling apart, or have crazed looniees trying to kill you.

That said there are a few low points about the graphics, some stuff feels VERY Copy and Paste, like i never enjoyed going into the bars because they felt too similar to each other, I might just be oblivious since I don't go to pubs in the real world but I would assume at least SOME differance also while I get this is meant to be a city that is collapsing from the inside but I think there is way too much grey around, its a typical gripe with FPS games in the last 10 or so years bit I still belive it to be a valid complaint

Next the sound, Honestly I didn't find the music that good, thats not a bad thing though as the lack of music or the sound of old style music playing from old radios helps add to the atmosphere, I don't know if this is a glitch though but sometimes when there was alot of shooting and such random audio bits would cut off, a prime example would be when I fought the first boss" of the game (not the Big Daddys) I had 2 Flying guns (Buzzers I called them) and a turret shooting at him

reviewText:
This isn't your ordinary CoD or BF, this is an adventure. Explore the underwater city of Rapture, a once beautiful landscape. Use a variety of special powers called plasmids. This game has it all.
--- Pros ---
interesting/fun gameplay
great graphics
great plot

--- Cons ---
Few bugs/glitches
minor sound concern
Compared to present games (2014) might not be the best (this game was released in 2007).

---Gameplay---
Bioshock allows you many ways to kill: plasmids, weapons, or both. As you progress in the game, you decide if you want to play stealthy (avoid cameras and turrets, secretly walk past enemies) or just go full berserk and kill whatever you fine. The game also has a variety of fun plasmids that let you choose your own way of killing, protection, or just some fun. The weapons, dang.The the game doesn't have like the same ammount of weapons as borderlands, quite a few actually, but they all have a different style and heck, you might prefer burning people, or just beating them up with a wrench, or maybe the classive inserting bullets" with the submachine gun. reviewText: On my xbox, I beat this game seven times. I have well over a hundred hours, maybe even two hundred plus. It is my favorite game of all time, and forever will be. The story is written so well and every character is memorable, and the the world of Rapture is just so immesive to be in. Gameplay is also very very fun. It is in depth but not complex. That is a perk. This game will always be my favorite game, and if it isn't your's that's fine. If you haven't gave Bioshock a go, you must. Bioshock Infinite is another favorite, and I also recommend Systemshock 2.

reviewText:
A truly stunning game that is utterly amazing and that I would highly recommend buying. It is a very fun fps that you can either breeze through or challenge yourself. It also has a beautiful, beautiful story, this is a game where you go out of your way to find out as much of the story line you just can. The combat is very fun and gives a new play style to fps and is a very unique game which is just wonderfully done.

A few things

If you are weak at horror games this might be a little scary and I myself got a bit a scared on some parts. While it may be creepy I do not believe it to be a true horror game rather jut creepy and gory.

It has recordings on parts and I would recommend finding as many of those as you can even if you it isn’t necessary it just adds to the games feel and gives a more fun experience.

The game is very different from the average shooter and the combat is very enjoyable with many different powers and plasmids (awesome powers that you shoot out from your hand) you get to freeze, burn, sting (yes sting with bees), electrocute and blow up your foes.

The story is very, very good and has a pretty well done ending that was satisfying and I myself intend to play it again and try to find a few of the recordings I missed.

reviewText:
I have played this on The Xbox 360, and just recently picked it up on Steam, the first two games were on sale back in December, and how could I NOT pick them up they are some of the most fantastic first person shooters I've played since the Doom 3 days. Today in gaming first person shooter just means Call of Duty Clone or something of that flavor, and it's kind of depressing most people think that.

This game you don't have infinite ammo, you have to worry about your health. The environment feels terrifying sometimes to the point where I just can't play the game, but that's cool, because I like to be scared out of a game from time to time.  Though I do wish you had more freedom around Rapture. It's just go here do this and onward. Sometimes you just want to putz around, but there's no way to do that without not progressing in the game.

If you haven't played this game before you NEED TO PICK THIS UP NOW AND PLAY THROUGH IT!

reviewText:
PLEASE NOTE!!!! This review is based on if you have NOT played any game in the bioshock series. Spoilers will attempt to be avoided, but that attempt may go wrong, read at your own risk.

As a side point, this is one of the first review's im writing for steam, so dont critique me on that aspect.

This review is present IGN style (Look em up on youtube), for a better, and visual review, look up Classic Game Room's review on youtube. I take no credit for either of these channels.

Storyline and Background: Bioshock takes place in the beautiful city of Rapture, situated somewhere at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. In the game you play an unnamed protagonist, who is later revealed to be a man named Jack, this is quite obvious and no spoiler. The game begins with a plane crash near a mysterious lighthouse, investigation leads you to one of the greatest introductory levels in games i have played. You enter a Bathysphere, a sort of diving pod, which takes you to Rapture, during the ride, you meet Andrew Ryan, the games antagonist for a majority of the gameplay, who talks to you about his beliefs, and what Rapture is economically, pure capitalism. Bioshock's story progresses confusingly, and realisticly, until the sudden plot twist later that changes the game from a struggle against a powerful genius, to a fight for survival against the armies of a power hungry man. Another interesting thing is that background story is told through the enviornment (only slightly), and audio diaries found throughout the game. Next up, Presentation and Sound Immersion.

Presentation and Sound Immersion: Bioshock is a completely gorgeous game, that is both immersive, and interesting. The art style depicts a wide array of colors and enviornments that is wonderful to look at. The enviornments, from the narrow passageways of Rapture's connection tubes, to the open spaces of the residential districts, are both realistic, and complicated. You want to explore all enviornments to find every bit of resources and information that you can, luckily a quest arrow at the tops points towards your goal once you get one, but it can be disabled in the main menu for a more immersive, and interesting experience. Sound effects are top notch, and add so much to Rapture's realistic yet confusing enviornment, from the strange chatter of the Little Sisters, to the deep growls and noises of the Big Daddies. Now, for Gameplay.

Gameplay: Bioshock's greatest selling point, to many, is it's gameplay. The game gives you a wide variety of weapons, from a simple wrench to the powerful crossbow, to kill your enemies, but that is not all that this game gives you. What makes the Bioshock series as a whole unique is its Plasmids and Gene Tonics. Throughout the game you will encounter Big Daddies, these large, hulking men in a diving suit are some of the toughest opponents in games. These Big Daddies protect the Little Sisters, in my opinion the most inconic and well known thing in Rapture. These Little Sisters harvest from corpses a genetic substance known as Adam, the most prestigous and valuable resource in the game, and the only way to get it is to harvest of rescue the Little Sister, which requires dealing with her Big Daddy first. Big Daddies are tough opponents even on easy, ESPECIALLY on your first or second time through the game, you can expect to die many times in the early Big Daddy fights. Their difficulty is balanced by the rewards obtained through Adam. Depending on if you harvest of rescue, you can either get more or less Adam, but if you do choose to rescue, the Little Sisters caretaker"

reviewText:
BioShock is a beautifully atmospheric game, with an excellent 60’s art deco style. The main selling point is the story, which is pretty damn great, and the world of BioShock is developed through Audio Logs and brilliant set piece moments. The guns are the standard setup of Melee, Pistol, Machine Gun, Shotgun, Grenade Launcher, Crossbow and the special weapon this time, the Chemical Thrower. Each of these weapons has 3 ammo types, standard ammo, Armour-Piercing and Anti-Personnel. In the supporting cast are ‘Plasmids’, powers such as Electro-Bolt, Incinerate! and Insect Swarm to name a few, powered by EVE.  Also, for some RPG-esq customization, they’re ‘Gene Tonics’, which you can equip, chop and change to your heart’s content. There’s a reasonable selection of dudes to fight, Melee, Gun wielding, Grenadiers and Spidery ones. The creepy Little Sisters wonder around BioShock, and gather ADAM, a wonder substance used for creating Plasmids and drugged up most of the people in the game. In Game, ADAM is used to buy and upgrade Plasmids/Gene Tonics, and presents the moral choice BioShock has. But first you have to fight Big Daddies, which at first is a big challenge, but then later is too much trouble.

However, it’s not without problems. BioShock is in no way challenging, and you get showered with Health Kits and items to recharge your EVE, and ammo. I didn’t really bother with the alternate ammo types, the regular types were just fine. I did go to the maximum slots for Plasmids and Gene Tonics, but I also found I was only using 3 Plasmids and about 4 Gene Tonics in each of the three categories. On the note of Gene Tonics, certain combinations are gross. For example, I was doing increased Wrench Damage, had silent footstep, received 25% less damage from most sources, 100% less damage taken from electricity while dishing out an additional 60%, and I did electrical damage whenever I got hit by a melee enemy. And that was only in combat! I had easier hacking, plus I received additional health from health kits, and an increased to both Health and EVE. ADAM simply isn’t as important as the game would have you believe, especially since how much of an effort it is to fight Big Daddies.

The Vending machines for ammo and general items were largely untouched by me, mainly for the reason that I didn’t need them, along with the half-arsed crafting system. I was only making Auto-Hack tools in the end, which brings us onto Hacking. Hacking is bloody awful, as you have to play Pipe Dreams to hack a system. In the end, I was just buying out or auto-hacking systems, as money was largely useless and I really couldn’t be arsed. A lack of inventory is also strange, so you eat food straight away as you pick it up, you never know how much of a weird item you’re carrying for crafting, and not being able to dual-wield Plasmids and a gun is really, really annoying, especially since you have to swap with right click.

Oh, and the final boss fight is awful.

Overall though, I really enjoyed BioShock, and would greatly recommend it, as all the problems I cited are largely insignificant in the grand scheme. As a final note, the whole 'Moral Choice' is a bit too Black and White, and something in the middle would have been much better.

reviewText:
I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this gem.

First I must say I tried it first on xbox360 and got kinda bored with it real quick, Tried it again on pc much later, (Maxed out and with a powerful rig)

The game is beautiful. Even now in 2011 (for a 2007 game its great looking) The water and lighting effects are phenomenal. Although character animations leave a little to be desired.

The sound is good, but cuts in and out quite a bit on stereo configuration.
The atmosphere is fantastic, and has quite a heavy mood.  The powers and weapons are plenty and for the most part all are very useful.   (Not to mention all the upgrades)

The gameplay is good. The gunplay is a little lacking, but core gameplay is really fun, especially with all the environment context reactions to your powers and special ammo.
The game is not Short by anymeans, and has plenty for you to search/explore and plenty of hidden goodies and secret locations in the game.

Story is great, but I will not spoil it

reviewText:
Loved this game. It may be a few years old, but I couldn't tell from the graphics, which were still stellar. The story is extremely well done and engaging throughout- you will be searching for every voxophone and going down every side corridor to learn more.

Gameplay was also very fun- I played on Normal difficulty, which was challenging enough that I was never bored, while not being hard enough that I was frustrated. There weren't too many weapons to choose from (and to be honest some just didn't seem that effective compared to the standard Wrench) but I never found myself bored or distracted by that fact. Same with the Plasmids (basically, magic spells)- I almost always used the standard Electric Shock, but the others were still interesting and the gameplay forced you to use some of the other Plasmids in order to unlock secret areas or find hidden voxophones which advanced the story.

In sum, I would give this game an 8/10, with a recommendation for people who want an engaging story to go with their gameplay.

reviewText: Bioshock is one of the greatest games that has ever been created in my opinion. The gameplay is solid, fun and with the combo of guns and plasmids; it just works really well. For the story, it is amazing, compelling and well writen it was a joy to keep playing to find out what was going to happen next and there's a really good plot twist in the end which I won't spoil. Theres replay value as there are choices throughout the game, although I can never bring myself to do anything but save the little sisters. Overall well worth the money.

reviewText: A steam punk horror FPS that will leave your jimmies quite rustled. Bioshock is the first game introduced into what would later become one of the best non-conforming FPS games to date. Filled with many twists and turns that will surely leave you scratching your head and really bringing the undersea world of Rapture to life. Bioshock is an intriguing title that tries, and sometimes fail, to spook you at every turn. The rusted and dilapidated environment accompanied with the pitter-patter of water hitting the  iron-clad walls and floor will bring the city of Rapture to life. An exhilarating story with many M. Night Shyamalan twists that really make the player sit down and think about what has happened through their experience in Rapture. A game that definitely has a story with a punch, but with some lacking basic fundamentals you'd expect to find in a FPS. Unfortunately, Bioshock isn't the best FPS for a number of reasons including difficulty when using spray (it's better to use guns as if they were semi-automatic for accuracy), a lot of the enemies move in strange ways that will cause them to complete dodge your shots if they're a certain distance from you (makes it very difficult unless you're aiming low when they are meleeing), and worst of all your only melee weapon is garbage even with all of the upgrades equipped. This makes medium to long range fights the best for you but there's constantly something running at you in your face. The FPS mechanics do take some getting used to and are pretty interesting, the fact that you don't zoom with right mouse button but with Z is definitely something most FPS don't do. Over the years the graphics have held up very well too and at the time of it's release it was hailed for it's intense computer requirements (thankfully much easier to acquire now). Bioshock is a title that deserves respect and while it's not fundamentally the best game the story is worth at least one trip though.\n\n☆★★★★ Overall  ☆★★★★ Gameplay  ★★★★★ Story  ☆★★★★ Graphics  ☆★★★★ Sounds  ☆★★★★ Oddity  ☆☆★★★ Length
